questions.text: A routine newborn screening test for phenylketonuria in a male neonate shows a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (N < 20). He is started on a special diet and the hyperphenylalaninemia resolves. At a routine well-child examination 4 months later, the physician notices that he has persistent head lag. On examination, he has blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, and generalized hypotonia. His serum prolactin level is markedly elevated. Supplementation of which of the following substances is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine supplementation along with dietary phenylalanine restriction is required in all forms of PKU. Patients with classic PKU (phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency) will not develop features of the disease if this dietary regimen is strictly followed. However, this infant most likely has malignant PKU, which requires an additional supplement to prevent further complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation along with a special cysteine-rich diet is used to treat homocystinuria that results from either cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity (of cystathionine synthase) for pyridoxal phosphate. Patients with homocystinuria can develop hypopigmentation of the hair and skin (as a result of tyrosinase inhibition by homocysteine) as well as hypotonia. However, homocystinuria is not associated with hyperprolactinemia and the newborn screening test would show increased levels of homocysteine and methionine rather than phenylalanine. Moreover, homocystinuria typically presents later during childhood with additional features such as intellectual disability, osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, kyphosis, lens subluxation, and accelerated atherosclerosis. Malignant PKU does not require pyridoxine supplementation.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) supplementation along with dietary restriction of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs; i.e., leucine, isoleucine, valine) is required in patients with maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). MSUD typically manifests in the early neonatal period with dystonia, recurrent vomiting, poor feeding, seizures, and a distinctive maple syrup odor in sweat and urine, none of which is seen here. Moreover, the newborn screening test would show increased levels of BCAAs and BCAA-keto acids rather than phenylalanine. Malignant PKU does not require thiamine supplementation.

D) CORRECT:

Malignant PKU (tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency) is caused by impaired tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) biosynthesis or recycling. BH4 is a cofactor for two enzymes of phenylalanine metabolism: phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine; and tyrosine hydroxylase, which converts tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). DOPA is a precursor for the synthesis of melanin, and catecholamines (e.g., dopamine). Since dopamine inhibits prolactin synthesis in the tuberoinfundibular pathway, patients with BH4 deficiency can develop hyperprolactinemia. Whereas classic PKU (phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency) can be treated with dietary phenylalanine restriction and tyrosine supplementation only, additional supplementation of BH4 is needed in malignant PKU.

Patients with malignant PKU can also develop serotonin deficiency since BH4 is also required for the conversion of tryptophan to serotonin.

E) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) supplementation along with a special high-protein diet is required in patients with Hartnup disease. This condition typically manifests with cerebellar ataxia (e.g., nystagmus, intention tremor), pellagra-like symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, dermatitis), and hyperpigmentation rather than pale skin. Hypotonia and hyperprolactinemia would not be expected. Features of Hartnup disease usually begin later during childhood and tend to occur intermittently during periods of acute stress (e.g., infection). Malignant PKU does not require niacin supplementation.
questions.hint: Increased levels of phenylalanine on newborn screening indicate phenylketonuria (PKU), which if inadequately treated can cause hypopigmentation (blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair) and generalized hypotonia. This patient presents with features of PKU despite dietary restriction and a decrease in serum phenylalanine concentration, which raises concern for malignant PKU.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after she observed jerking movements of his arms and legs for about 30 seconds earlier that morning. The patient is healthy apart from occasional bouts of eczema. He was delivered at home in Romania. His mother had no prenatal care. She reports that he has required more time to reach developmental milestones compared to his older brother. The patient's immunization records are not available. He takes no medications. He appears pale with blue eyes and has a musty odor. He has poor eye contact. Which of the following would have most likely prevented the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism in the mother during pregnancy is associated with birth complications, premature birth, low birth weight, cognitive impairment, and an increased risk of respiratory distress syndrome. While this patient shows signs of developmental delay, seizures, pale skin, and a musty odor suggest another diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine results in PKU. PKU is associated with developmental delay beginning at 4â€“6 months, hypopigmentation of the irises, hair, and skin (because tyrosine is a precursor to melanin), a musty odor, and seizures in approx. 50% of patients. In the US, phenylalanine level measurement is part of the standard newborn screening and can only be refused if it is in conflict with the parents' religious practices or beliefs. In this case, however, access to newborn screening may have been limited. Management consists of a low phenylalanine and high tyrosine diet (tyrosine becomes a nutritionally essential amino acid in patients with PKU).

C) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol is used to treat Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. While patients with Lesch-Nyhan may show a cognitive delay, this patient's musty odor, pale skin, and seizures are not characteristic of this disease. Instead, patients with Lesch-Nyhan may demonstrate choreoathetotic movement, delayed growth and puberty, self-mutilating behavior, and gouty arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Avoidance of fasting states may help patients with medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCAD deficiency) avoid states of hypoglycemia, vomiting, and lethargy. Pale skin, blue eyes, cognitive delay, and a musty odor are not components of MCAD deficiency, however.

E) INCORRECT:

High doses of vitamin B6 can be used in the treatment of homocystinuria, which is usually caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency. As a cofactor for this enzyme, vitamin B6 increases its activity. While homocystinuria may be associated with developmental delay and seizures, a musty odor and pale skin are not characteristics of the disease. Patients with homocystinuria instead may have lens dislocation and myopia, elongated bones, and a predisposition to thrombosis.

F) INCORRECT:

L-iduronidase replacement is used in the treatment of Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I). While this disease is associated with cognitive impairment, it is not characterized by pale skin, blue eyes, musty odor, or seizures. Rather, patients with Hurler syndrome may exhibit dysmorphic facial features, joint contractures, failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, or corneal clouding.
questions.hint: This infant may not have had access to newborn screening. Developmental delay, seizure, pale skin, blue eyes, musty odor, and a history of eczema are consistent with phenylketonuria (PKU).

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of delay in attaining developmental milestones. He could sit upright by 14 months and has not been able to walk without support. He can build a tower of 3 blocks but cannot use utensils to feed himself. He speaks in unclear 2-word phrases and cannot draw a circle yet. His mother has noticed him hitting his head against the wall on multiple occasions. He is at 20th percentile for height and at 50th percentile for weight. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple lacerations of his lips and tongue. There are multiple healing wounds over his fingers. Neurological examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL


Mean corpuscular volume
103 Î¼m3



Serum



 Na+

142 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 K+

4.1 mEq/L


 Creatinine
1.6 mg/dL


 Uric acid

12.3 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

FMR1 (fragile X mental retardation 1) gene mutation causes Fragile X syndrome. Fragile X syndrome can manifest with developmental delay and hypotonia, but not elevated serum uric acid levels, macrocytic anemia, or the self-injurious behavior seen in this patient. Instead, it is associated with specific physical anomalies (e.g., large ears and jaw, macrocephaly), above (rather than below) average height, and epilepsy.

B) INCORRECT:

MECP2 (methyl-CpG binding protein 2) gene mutation causes Rett syndrome. Rett syndrome presents with progressive intellectual disability and loss of speech after several months to years of normal development. The condition is also associated with the development of stereotypic hand wringing movements and ataxia. It does not present with self-injurious behavior, macrocytic anemia, or elevated serum uric acid levels. Additionally, because afflicted males die in utero or shortly after birth, Rett syndrome is seen almost exclusively in females.

C) INCORRECT:

Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency can cause maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). While patients with MSUD can also present with dystonia and cognitive impairment, they pass urine with a characteristic maple syrup odor and classically develop ketonuria and lethargy shortly after birth. MSUD would not be associated with self-injurious behavior, macrocytic anemia, or elevated serum uric acid.

D) CORRECT:

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked condition caused by a mutation of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), impairing the conversion of hypoxanthine and resulting in increased levels of uric acid. Although patients already have hyperuricemia at birth, they are usually asymptomatic for the first few months of life, except for the orange sand-like sodium urate crystals that are found in the diapers of affected infants. Neurological features, which often appear around 4â€“6 months of age, include development delay, behavioral symptoms (aggressiveness, self-injurious behavior), and pyramidal (e.g., spasticity) and extrapyramidal symptoms (e.g., dystonia). Hypotonia can also occur early in the disease course. These cognitive and neuromuscular deficits lead to difficulties walking and affected children typically require a wheelchair. Accumulation of uric acid in peripheral tissues can eventually result in gouty arthritis, urate nephropathy, and megaloblastic anemia. Treatment involves allopurinol and a diet low in purines (to avoid metabolization into uric acid). There is no treatment for the underlying enzyme defect.

To remember the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which is involved in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, think: Hyperuricemia, Gout, Poor intellect, Rage/aggression, abnormal muscle Tone.

E) INCORRECT:

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency is a rare cause of severe combined immunodeficiency. While it can also manifest with developmental delay and muscular hypertonia, the underlying immune defect would also cause severe recurrent bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency is not associated with self-injurious behavior and presents with low (rather than elevated) serum uric acid levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Uridine monophosphate synthetase deficiency can cause orotic aciduria, which also presents with macrocytic (megaloblastic) anemia and, in some cases, cognitive impairment. However, patients with orotic aciduria usually have low (rather than high) serum uric acid levels. Finally, increased muscle tone and self-injurious behavior are not associated with orotic aciduria, making this diagnosis unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Microdeletion of the paternal chromosome 15 causes Prader-Willi syndrome, which may manifest with short stature. However, the disease is not associated with elevated serum uric acid levels, macrocytic anemia, or self-injurious behavior, as seen in this patient. Instead, it manifests with profound muscular hypotonia (rather than hypertonia), increased appetite leading to obesity, genital hypoplasia, and dysmorphic facial features (e.g., almond-shaped eyes), all of which are absent here.

H) INCORRECT:

Iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency causes Hunter syndrome. While Hunter syndrome can cause neurocognitive decline and hyperactive aggressive behavior, it is also associated with dysmorphic facial features, skeletal abnormalities (dysostosis), hepatosplenomegaly, and deafness, none of which are present in this patient. In addition, Hunter syndrome is not associated with self-injurious behavior, macrocytic anemia, or elevated serum uric acid.
questions.hint: The presence of developmental delay, abnormal muscle tone, and self-injurious behavior in a boy with macrocytic anemia, increased creatinine, and hyperuricemia indicate Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He started walking at 20 months of age. He can use a cup to drink but cannot use silverware. He speaks in 2-word sentences and can build a tower of 4 blocks. He can scribble but cannot draw a circle. He is above the 99th percentile for height and at the 15th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral inferior lens dislocation. His fingers are long and slender. He has a high-arched palate. The thumb and 5th finger overlap when he grips a wrist with the opposite hand. The skin over the neck can be extended and stretched easily. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine-phosphoribosyl transferase deficiency (HGPRT) leads to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This patient's developmental delay (indicative of underlying intellectual disability) is consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. However, there is no history of self-injurious behavior or evidence of excessive uric acid (chronic arthropathy or acute gout), which are hallmarks of the disease. Additionally, this patient's clinical findings are not associated with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the FBN1 gene (also known as fibrillin-1) result in Marfan syndrome. Patients with this gene mutation present with a marfanoid habitus, similar to the patient described here. However, Marfan syndrome does not account for this patient's delayed developmental milestones (the condition is not known to cause intellectual disability). Moreover, inferior lens dislocation makes Marfan syndrome less likely, because the condition is classically associated with lens dislocation in the superotemporal direction.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the COL5A1 gene lead to defective type V collagen. This gene mutation is associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which presents with excessive skin laxity, hypermobile joints, and a tendency towards spontaneous bleeding. Although this patient has hypermobile joints and skin laxity, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome would not explain the abnormalities seen on the ocular exam or the failure to meet normal developmental milestones.

D) CORRECT:

Cystathionine synthase deficiency causes homocystinuria, which is consistent with this patient who presents with marfanoid habitus, a high-arched palate, inferior lens dislocation, hyperelastic skin, and hypermobile joints. This boy's delay in language, block-building, and drawing abilities may indicate intellectual disability, another feature that is often observed in patients with cystathionine synthase deficiency.

A deficiency in this enzyme leads to excessive homocysteine in the blood and urine; the addition of sodium nitroprusside will turn these patients' urine a deep red color, confirming the presence of homocysteine and the diagnosis. Homocystinuria due to cystathionine synthase deficiency is treated with a low methionine, high cysteine diet, and supplementation with vitamin B12 and folate (vitamin B9). Some patients respond well to large doses of pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Homocystinuria is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis and thrombotic events (specifically, myocardial infarction and stroke).

E) INCORRECT:

Galactokinase deficiency is the hereditary absence or reduced activity of galactokinase. This error in galactose metabolism results in a relatively mild phenotype and would not account for the abnormal physical exam findings or delayed developmental milestones observed in this child.
questions.hint: Vitamin B9 and vitamin B12 are used to treat this condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of crushing chest pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The pain is constant and radiates to his left shoulder. Over the past year, he has been admitted to the hospital twice for deep vein thrombosis. He has a history of learning disability and has been held back three grades. The patient is at the 99th percentile for height and the 45th percentile for weight. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. His fingers are long and slender, and his arm span exceeds his body height. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2. His serum troponin I concentration is 2.0 ng/mL. Coronary angiography shows 90% occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral gynecomastia is a possible manifestation of Klinefelter syndrome. Individuals with this sex chromosome disorder typically have a tall stature with long extremities and may present with a learning disability. However, Klinefelter syndrome is not associated with arachnodactyly, early-onset coronary heart disease, or thromboembolic events. Instead, symptoms related to testosterone deficiency (e.g., testicular hypoplasia, reduced body hair, osteoporosis) would be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Homocystinuria is a group of autosomal recessive metabolic disorders characterized by downward lens subluxation, a marfanoid habitus, intellectual disability, early-onset atherosclerosis, and increased risk of thromboembolic events (e.g., DVTs). Other clinical features may include myopia, pale skin, osteoporosis, and kyphosis. This condition is caused by several enzyme defects (e.g., cystathionine synthase deficiency, methionine synthase deficiency, and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase deficiency), all of which result in the accumulation of homocysteine. Treatment depends on the underlying defect (e.g., cysteine, vitamin B6, vitamin B12, folate supplementation).

Marfan syndrome is an important differential diagnosis of homocystinuria. Distinguishing features include intellectual disability, which is only seen in homocystinuria, and the direction of lens dislocation (downwards in homocystinuria; upwards in Marfan syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Macroorchidism is a possible manifestation of Fragile X syndrome, a condition associated with intellectual disability and tall stature. However, early-onset coronary heart disease and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with Fragile X syndrome. Instead, features such as a long and narrow face, large ears, mitral valve prolapse, and hyperactivity would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Saccular cerebral aneurysms are a possible complication of Ehler-Danlos syndrome (EDS). This patient has a marfanoid habitus, which can be seen in some types of EDS. However, learning disability, early-onset coronary heart disease, and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with EDS. Moreover, EDS is associated with further clinical features such as skin hyperextensibility, a tendency to bleed, and mitral valve prolapse.

E) INCORRECT:

Mucosal neuromas are a possible feature of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN 2B), a syndrome commonly associated with a marfanoid habitus. However, learning disability, early-onset coronary heart disease, and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with this condition. Moreover, MEN 2B is characterized by further neoplasms such as pheochromocytoma and early-onset medullary thyroid carcinoma (in 95â€“100% of patients with MEN 2B).

F) INCORRECT:

Aneurysm of the ascending aorta is a possible complication of Marfan syndrome. This patient has a marfanoid habitus; however, learning disability, early-onset coronary heart disease, and recurrent thromboembolic events are inconsistent with Marfan syndrome. Moreover, although compression of a coronary artery by an aortic aneurysm can result in myocardial infarction, this patient's coronary angiography indicates underlying coronary artery atherosclerosis.
questions.hint: The patient's early-onset coronary heart disease and marfanoid habitus (tall and thin stature with increased arm span, arachnodactyly) in combination with a history of deep vein thromboses (DVTs) and learning disability raise suspicion for homocystinuria.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a pruritic rash on her face and extremities for the last year that increases with sun exposure. Her parents report that she often seems clumsy and has had several falls in the last two weeks. Physical examination shows an erythematous, scaly rash with hyperpigmentation over the nasal bridge and cheeks as well as on the dorsal forearms and hands. Urinalysis shows high levels of neutral amino acids. The most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition includes administration of an agent that is associated with which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrocalcinosis is seen in patients with chronic hypercalcemia, which can result from vitamin D hyperalimentation. In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin D supplementation. Vitamin D deficiency occurs in patients with malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (D, E, A, and K) rather than neutral amino acids. In children, this deficiency causes rickets.

B) INCORRECT:

Bleeding complications such as hemorrhagic stroke or necrotizing enterocolitis (in infants) can result from vitamin E excess because large amounts of vitamin E impair absorption of procoagulatory vitamin K. In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin E supplementation. Though vitamin E deficiency may present with neurological deficits, such as ataxia and muscular weakness, it occurs in patients with impaired fat reabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease), which does not explain this patient's isolated neutral aminoaciduria.

C) CORRECT:

Treatment of Hartnup disease consists of both niacin supplementation (nicotinic acid) to correct vitamin B3 deficiency and replenishing the constant loss of amino acids with a high-protein diet. One of the most prominent side effects of niacin is facial flushing due to an increase in prostaglandin synthesis (leads to cutaneous vasodilation). Aspirin or ibuprofen, taken 30â€“60 minutes prior to administration of niacin, helps suppress prostaglandin production by inactivating cyclooxygenase.

Other adverse effects of niacin include hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia.
Image Description:

There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the â€œ4 D's of pellagraâ€ alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

D) INCORRECT:

Iatrogenic pseudotumor cerebri can result from chronic vitamin A toxicity (e.g., due to long-term supplementation). In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin A supplementation. Vitamin A deficiency results from impaired fat reabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease) rather than malabsorption of neutral amino acids, and manifests with dry skin, night blindness, keratomalacia, and immunosuppression.

E) INCORRECT:

Medication-induced, irreversible retinopathy is a side effect of hydroxychloroquine, which is used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus. SLE can also present with a rash, photosensitivity, and proteinuria, as seen in this 5-year-old patient. However, it would not explain her isolated neutral aminoaciduria, which is highly specific for Hartnup disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate kidney stones can result from excessive supplementation of vitamin C (breaks down into oxalate). In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin C supplementation. While Vitamin C deficiency can present with generalized weakness, patients usually have other symptoms, such as swollen gums, poor wound healing, perifollicular hemorrhage, and mucosal bleeding.
questions.hint: Intestinal and renal loss of neutral amino acids (e.g., tryptophan) is characteristic of Hartnup disease. Because tryptophan is a precursor of endogenous synthesis of vitamin B3, its loss results in vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency and symptoms of pellagra (rash on sun-exposed skin, ataxia with clumsiness, and recurrent falls).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic counseling prior to conception. Her younger brother has mild developmental delay, pale complexion, and has to limit his dietary intake of phenylalanine. She has no similar symptoms and is in good health. Her parents are healthy. Which of the following is the most appropriate assessment of her carrier status for the disease affecting her brother?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This woman's parents had a 25% chance of having a child who is unaffected and not a carrier (AA), a 50% chance of having a child who is a heterozygous (Aa) carrier, and a 25% chance of having a child who is affected (aa). Since this woman is phenotypically unaffected, she has a 0% chance of being homozygous (aa). Therefore, she has a 33.3% chance of not being a carrier (AA) and a 66.7% chance of being a carrier (Aa).
Image Description:

In an autosomal recessive inheritance, two copies of a disease allele (a) located on autosomes are needed to be passed from the parents to the offspring to cause the expression of the phenotype. In this inheritance pattern, affected individuals are present not in every generation. Males and females are equally affected. The parents of an affected individual are usually not affected but carry the causative allele. Autosomal recessive inheritance is common in consanguineous families because of the increased risk of carriage of recessive alleles.

A: healthy allele

B) INCORRECT:

This represents the likelihood of the patient being genotypically and phenotypically healthy, without being a carrier (e.g., homozygous AA).

Recognize phenylketonuria, and calculate the carrier status probability in the first-degree sibling of a patient with an autosomal recessive disease.

Identify phenylketonuria and calculate carrier probability in first-degree sibling of autosomal recessive disease patient.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient would have a 100% chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) if one parent were phenotypically and genotypically healthy (e.g., AA) and the other parent were phenotypically affected (aa), or if her parents were a heterozygous carrier (Aa) and phenotypically affected (aa).

D) INCORRECT:

This woman's parents had a 75% overall chance that their child would be asymptomatic (i.e., phenotypically healthy); 25% (AA) plus 50% (Aa). Considering that this woman cannot be homozygous for the phenylketonuria allele (aa), her individual chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) is not 75%.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient would have a 50% chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) if her health status was unknown. However, we know that this woman is phenotypically unaffected. Therefore, she cannot be homozygous for the phenylketonuria allele (aa) and her individual chance of being a heterozygous carrier (Aa) is not 50%.
questions.hint: Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disease, which means both of the patient's parents must be heterozygous carriers (Aa) as they are both phenotypically unaffected and have a phenotypically affected child (aa).

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of lethargy and vomiting since he woke up 1 hour ago. The mother says that he last breastfed the previous evening and slept through the night for the first time. His family recently immigrated from Bolivia. His temperature is 38.7Â°C (101.7Â°F). Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and enlarged, reddened tonsils. Serum studies show:


Glucose
42 mg/dL


Ketones

0.2 mg/dL (N â‰¤ 1)


AST
76 U/L


ALT
120 U/L


Ammonia

80 Î¼/dL (N = 15â€“45)


Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes classic phenylketonuria due to a toxic build-up of phenylalanine. The disease has an insidious onset and causes a pale skin (due to lack of tyrosine), musty body odor, failure to thrive, loss of motor control, intellectual disability, and seizure. This patient does not have these features.

B) CORRECT:

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) degrades medium-chain fatty acids into acetyl-CoA in the mitochondria (Î²-oxidation). Acetyl-CoA is used for allosteric modulation of pyruvate carboxylase (to promote gluconeogenesis), ATP generation (in Krebs cycle), or ketone body formation. When glucose and glycogen stores are depleted, for example, after this patient's fasting (e.g., during weaning, skipping nightly feeds) or a state of increased metabolic demand (e.g., infection, exercise), the body normally relies on fatty acid metabolism. But in patients with MCAD deficiency, a deficit of acetyl-CoA develops, which leads to hyperammonemia, hypoglycemia without ketosis, vomiting, and lethargy, as seen in this patient. Without intervention, the condition can progress to seizure and coma.

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency is routinely screened in neonates. To prevent symptoms, patients are advised to adopt a diet consisting of frequent high-carbohydrate and low-fat meals and avoid fasting or metabolic decompensation.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency causes Hurler syndrome, a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by intracellular glycosaminoglycan accumulation. Patients present with developmental delay, corneal clouding, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated urine glycosaminoglycan concentration. This patient does not have these features.

D) INCORRECT:

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency causes classic galactosemia; this enzyme converts galactose-1-phosphate into uridine diphosphate galactose (UDP-galactose). Hence, galactose-1-phosphate and its toxic byproducts (galactitol) will accumulate inside cells when infants start breastfeeding. Presenting features include nausea, vomiting, cataracts, hepatosplenomegaly, seizure, and failure to thrive. Although this patient has vomiting and lethargy, he lacks other clinical features despite breastfeeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Propionyl-CoA carboxylase catalyzes the conversion of propionyl-CoA, which is a catabolic byproduct of odd-chain fatty acid and certain essential amino acids (valine, isoleucine, methionine, threonine), into methylmalonyl-CoA. Hence, deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of propionic acid and ammonia. Although patients with propionyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency present with vomiting, lethargy, and hyperammonemia, they have ketoacidosis, unlike this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Lysosomal acid Î±-1,4- glucosidase deficiency causes Pompe disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of lysosomal glycogen-like inclusions. The disease predominantly affects tissues with high glycogen stores such as liver, muscle, and heart. Hence, the presenting clinical features include hypotonia, exercise intolerance, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which are not present in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of vomiting, lethargy, hypoglycemia, and hyperammonemia without compensatory ketosis after both night-time fasting and a presumed URTI (fever, enlarged and reddened tonsils) indicates a problem with the metabolism of a ketone precursor.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of fatigue and generalized weakness for 4 months. Examination shows decreased muscle tone. Her fasting serum glucose concentration is 41 mg/dL. The physician suspects a defect in one of the enzymes involved in the carnitine shuttle. Increased serum concentration of which of the following would be inconsistent with this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Î²-hydroxybutyrate is a ketone body that is produced in the mitochondrial matrix via beta-oxidation. A dysfunctional carnitine shuttle precludes the entrance of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix, decreasing the available substrate for beta-oxidation, which results in hypoketonemia. Increased serum ketones would therefore indicate a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Alanine aminotransferase is commonly elevated in patients with carnitine shuttle defects, as fatty acids released from adipose tissue cannot enter mitochondria to undergo beta-oxidation. This results in the accumulation of fat in the liver, leading to hepatic steatosis, liver damage, and elevated transaminases.

C) INCORRECT:

Acylcarnitine is formed during fatty acid degradation when carnitine palmitoyltransferase 1 (CPT1) links carnitine with a fatty acyl group, the second of four steps in the multistep carnitine shuttle. Acylcarnitine concentrations are elevated in carnitine shuttle defects occurring downstream from CPT1 (e.g., defective transport of carnitine-fatty acid complexes across the mitochondrial membrane by acylcarnitine translocase, or defective removal of carnitine from the complex by carnitine palmitoyltransferase 2, or CPT2, once within the mitochondria). The vast majority of carnitine shuttle defects are therefore associated with elevated levels of acylcarnitine.

Carnitine transporter deficiency, another carnitine shuttle defect, affects the step prior to CPT1, preventing carnitine from being moved across the cell membrane into the cytosol and the formation of acylcarnitine, which results in low serum acylcarnitine concentrations.

D) INCORRECT:

Uric acid levels can be increased in patients with carnitine shuttle defects in which the underlying problem is a defective carnitine transporter, which is responsible for moving carnitine from outside the cell membrane into the cytosol. The lack of such a transporter leads to accumulation of excessive carnitine in the blood as well as urinary carnitine loss. Hyperuricemia develops as a result of uric acid competing with excess carnitine for renal tubular excretion.

E) INCORRECT:

Ammonia levels are often increased in patients with carnitine shuttle defects because of the accumulation of non-metabolized fat in the liver. This, in turn, leads to hepatic steatosis, liver damage, and hyperammonemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Creatine kinase levels are usually elevated in patients with carnitine shuttle defects, although the precise mechanism of this increase is not yet fully understood. It is assumed that deficiency of ATP during exercise causes muscle cell instability, which results in the release of creatine kinase.
questions.hint: A defect in the carnitine shuttle would result in impaired transport of long-chain fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane and, subsequently, deficient beta-oxidation.

questions.text: An 8-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting and poor feeding. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and he was born at full term. He appears pale and lethargic. Physical examination shows diffusely increased muscle tone. His urine is noted to have a sweet odor. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by the accumulation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (valine, leucine, isoleucine) due to a deficiency of branched-chain Î±-ketoacid dehydrogenase causes MSUD. If untreated, affected neonates develop severe CNS damage, which can lead to coma and death. MSUD can be diagnosed by the presence of alpha-ketoacids of branched chain amino acids in serum. Treatment involves avoidance of dietary branched-chain amino acids and thiamine supplementation.

B) INCORRECT:

Phytanic acid accumulation occurs in patients with Refsum disease. Patients with this condition typically develop scaly skin, ataxia, sensorineural hearing loss, and vision loss during adolescence but are asymptomatic during childhood. Refsum disease does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

C) INCORRECT:

Homogentisic acid accumulation occurs in patients with homogentisate oxidase deficiency (alkaptonuria). Patients with this condition can develop ochronosis as adults but are typically asymptomatic during childhood. Urine may become darker on prolonged exposure to air but alkaptonuria does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

D) INCORRECT:

Homocysteine accumulation occurs with hereditary deficiency of cystathionine synthase or methionine synthase. Neonates with either of these deficiencies are typically asymptomatic but older children can present with osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke, coronary artery disease), and/or failure to thrive. Homocystinuria does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine accumulation occurs in patients with phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (phenylketonuria). This condition causes a musty odor in the urine, not a sweet-smelling odor. Moreover, symptoms of phenylketonuria (e.g. seizures, delayed development, intellectual disability, eczema) do not manifest until 2â€“4 weeks after birth due to the presence of maternal phenylalanine hydroxylase in the baby's serum.
questions.hint: Poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and hypertonia are nonspecific symptoms; however, the presence of a sweet-smelling urine strongly raises the suspicion of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of difficulty walking for 6 months. His mother reports that over the past year, he has been clumsy and does not seem to be able to concentrate when encouraged to play with his toys. During infancy, he had an episode of tonic-clonic seizure after an upper respiratory infection that required intubation. He is at the 10th percentile for length and below the 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows muscles that resist passive stretch and spastic movements of the upper and lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 throughout. Serum studies show:


Glucose
90 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
2 mg/dL


Ammonia

80 Î¼mol/L (N = 11â€“35)



Urine



Orotic acid
increased


The results of a liver biopsy show that the hepatocytes are deficient in a particular enzyme. The enzyme is normally located in the cytosol of hepatocytes and the substrate of this enzyme is a proteinogenic amino acid that has a positive charge at a pH of 7.4. The patient most likely has a deficiency in which of the following labeled enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1) catalyzes the formation of carbamoyl phosphate from bicarbonate and ammonia. CPS1 deficiency causes hyperammonemia but CPS I is located in hepatic mitochondria rather than in cytosol, and its deficiency does not cause orotic acid accumulation in the urine. Additionally, neither bicarbonate nor ammonia are amino acids.

B) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) catalyzes the formation of citrulline from carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine. Ornithine has a positive charge at a pH of 7.4 and OTC deficiency, which is the most common urea cycle disorder, causes hyperammonemia and increased urine orotic acid concentrations. However, OTC is located in hepatic mitochondria rather than cytosol and ornithine is not a proteinogenic amino acid.

C) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinate synthetase catalyzes the formation of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate. This enzyme is located in the cytosol of hepatocytes and a deficiency of this enzyme can result in hyperammonemia and increased urine concentrations of orotic acid. However, citrulline is a nonproteinogenic amino acid with no charge at normal body pH (7.4) and although aspartate is proteinogenic, aspartate has a negative charge at normal body pH. A different amino acid involved in the urea cycle is both proteinogenic and positively charged at normal body pH.

D) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinate lyase, which catalyzes the breakdown of argininosuccinate to arginine and fumarate, is located in the cytosol of hepatocytes and a deficiency of this enzyme can cause hyperammonemia and an increase in urine concentrations of orotic acid. However. fumarate is not an amino acid, and although argininosuccinate is a basic amino acid, argininosuccinate is not proteinogenic.

E) CORRECT:

A defect of any enzyme involved in the urea cycle will cause the accumulation of ammonia and a decrease in the concentration of blood urea nitrogen. The urea cycle, which occurs in hepatocytes, involves the mitochondrial enzymes carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I) and ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) and the cytosolic enzymes argininosuccinate synthetase, argininosuccinate lyase, and arginase. Arginase catalyzes the breakdown of arginine, a proteinogenic amino acid with a positive charge at normal body pH (7.4), into urea and ornithine. Carbamoyl phosphate also accumulates in all urea cycle enzyme defects except CPS I deficiency. Carbamoyl phosphate is diverted to the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, causing an increase in orotic acid in serum and its subsequent excretion in urine.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.
questions.hint: This patient's developmental delay, failure to thrive, seizures, and muscle spasticity and weakness are likely due to his hyperammonemia. These features in combination with decreased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and increased urinary orotic acid suggest a urea cycle disorder. A proteinogenic amino acid is one that is encoded by a codon and can be a component of a protein's primary structure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for genetic consultation. She has a history of recurrent generalized seizures, diffuse muscular weakness, and multiple episodes of transient left-sided paresis. She has been hospitalized several times for severe lactic acidosis requiring intravenous fluid hydration. Her 10-year-old daughter also has seizures and muscle weakness. Her 7-year-old son has occasional muscle weakness and headaches but has never had a seizure. Pathologic examination of a biopsy specimen from the woman's soleus muscle shows ragged-appearing muscle fibers. Genetic analysis of the patient's son is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Altered allele on the X chromosome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Silencing of either a maternal or paternal gene copy via methylation is known as genomic imprinting. When genomic imprinting occurs, mutation or deletion of the other gene copy can lead to disorders. A silenced paternal gene copy with a deleted or mutated maternal allele is not associated with MELAS syndrome but causes Angelman syndrome. Although this condition could explain this patient's seizures, other important manifestations, such as intellectual disability and outbursts of inappropriate laughter, would be expected. In addition, Angelman syndrome would not explain this patient's muscle weakness, lactic acidosis, strokes, or biopsy findings.

B) CORRECT:

Diseases caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), such as MELAS syndrome in this patient, can only be passed onto offspring from the mother because mtDNA is maternally inherited. A woman transmits the pathogenic variants in mtDNA to all of her offspring. However, patients with MELAS syndrome usually show heteroplasmy, which explains the son's and daughter's different presentation.
Image Description:

Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutation in DNA repair genes, such as BRCA, leads to fewer mutations being enzymatically repaired, which can cause chromosomal instability and potentially cancer. Chromosomal instability syndromes (e.g., Fanconi anemia) can be spontaneous, or inherited as in this patient. However, MELAS syndrome is not caused by DNA repair gene mutations.

D) INCORRECT:

Cell lines with different genotypes within one organism are found in mosaicism, which does not cause MELAS syndrome but may be seen, for example, in Turner syndrome or mosaic Down syndrome. These conditions seem unlikely here, as Turner syndrome is exclusively found in females, whereas features of mosaic Down syndrome (e.g., intellectual disability, upward-slanting palpebral fissures, single transverse palmar crease) are not present in these patients. Moreover, both conditions are not associated with tonic-clonic seizures, lactic acidosis, and recurrent strokes.

E) INCORRECT:

If genetic analysis of the patient's son showed an altered allele on the X chromosome, it could be either a recessive or a dominant mutation. An X-linked recessive inheritance is very unlikely since this patient's condition affects both the son and daughter, which implies that the father must be affected as well to pass on the mutation to the daughter as well. As for X-linked dominant inheritance, there are only a few rare syndromes such as Rett syndrome. This condition is typically seen in females starting at the age of two and can present with neurological symptoms, which do not include seizures but progressive loss of intelligence and loss of locomotion and fine motor skills.
questions.hint: This female patient's history of muscle weakness, tonic-clonic seizures, episodes of lactic acidosis, and possible recurrent strokes (i.e., episodes of unilateral paresis), in combination with a positive family history (suggesting a genetic cause), is consistent with MELAS syndrome. A muscle biopsy showing characteristic ragged red fibers confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening pain in his lower back, knees, and shoulders over the past few years. He used to be able to touch his fingers to his toes while standing; now he has difficulty touching his shins. He is wearing a shirt with dark brown stains around the armpits. Physical examination shows bluish-brown sclerae and thickening of the external ear. The range of motion of the affected joints is decreased. X-rays of the spine show calcification of multiple lumbar intervertebral discs. The patient's condition is most likely caused by impaired metabolism of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Homocysteine metabolism is impaired in homocystinuria, not in alkaptonuria. Homocystinuria typically manifests in infancy with failure to thrive or later with developmental delays, downward and inward lens subluxation, intellectual disability, Marfanoid habitus, and an increased risk of thromboembolic disease. Although this patient has skeletal abnormalities, they are due to arthritis and degenerative changes and not associated with a Marfanoid habitus. Moreover, obvious changes in pigmentation and calcification of connective tissue would not be expected in homocystinuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Tryptophan absorption, not metabolism, is impaired in Hartnup disease, due to a defect in Na+-dependent neutral amino acid transporters. As a result, synthesis of the tryptophan-based vitamin niacin is impaired, which may lead to symptoms of pellagra. Patients with pellagra typically present with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, while this patient has an entirely different set of features.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, â€œdeathâ€ is sometimes still listed as the fourth â€œDâ€ of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoxanthine metabolism is impaired in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, not in alkaptonuria. In Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, accumulation of uric acid (hyperuricemia) leads to symptoms such as developmental delay, dystonia, gout, and self-mutilating behavior, normally within the first years of life, whereas this patient is already 35 years old. Further, ochronosis, arthritis, and degenerative changes of the vertebral column would not be expected in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Alkaptonuria is a tyrosine metabolism disorder caused by deficient activity of the enzyme homogentisic acid dioxygenase, which catalyzes the degradation of homogentisate to 4-maleylacetoacetate. This leads to accumulation of pigment-forming homogentisate in the serum and the tissues, resulting in ochronosis of the connective tissue. Calcification of the heart valves and nephrolithiasis may also be seen in alkaptonuria, typically affecting patients above 50 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Ornithine metabolism is impaired in ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, the most common urea cycle disorder, which leads to hyperammonemia. Patients with OTC deficiency typically present during the first years of life with nausea, vomiting, delayed growth, psychiatric symptoms, and, in severe cases, seizures, whereas this patient is already 35 years old. Furthermore, ochronosis, arthritis, and degenerative changes of the vertebral column would not be expected in OTC deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient has features of ochronosis: dark sweat stains, bluish-brown sclerae, and thickening of external ear cartilage. Together with his arthritis and degenerative changes in the vertebral column, this is highly suggestive of alkaptonuria.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a seizure. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is currently at the 10th percentile for height, 5th percentile for weight, and 15th percentile for head circumference. Examination shows muscle hypotonia. His serum lactic acid and alanine are elevated. A functional assay of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex in serum leukocytes shows decreased enzyme activity. Supplementation with which of the following substances should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arachidonic acid is used as a nutritional supplement in infant formulas to promote neurodevelopment. Since PDHC is not involved in fatty acid metabolism, supplementation would not worsen symptoms of PDHC deficiency. Rather, it is recommended that this patient follow a high-fat diet, as it will provide an alternative source of energy when his body is deprived of carbohydrates.

B) CORRECT:

Valine supplementation should be avoided in patients with PDHC deficiency. In normal metabolism, the PDHC is an important enzyme complex linking the end product of glycolysis (pyruvate) with the starting reactant of the citric acid cycle (acetyl-CoA). In PDHC deficiency, however, pyruvate generated from glucose cannot be used as an energy source, causing a severe energy deficit. Since valine is a purely glucogenic amino acid, pyruvate will accumulate and get shunted to lactate and alanine, causing metabolic acidosis and worsening symptoms in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Lysine, just like leucine, is a purely ketogenic amino acid. Since it is not degraded to pyruvate, PDHC is not involved in its metabolism. Instead, the generated acetyl-CoA can be used for ATP synthesis in the citric acid cycle, so supplementation with leucine and lysine is suited for a patient with PDHC deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiamine supplementation is part of the treatment for PDHC deficiency, and therefore, it should not be avoided. The PDHC reaction requires several cofactors, including thiamine and lipoic acid. Stimulation of residual PDHC via supplementation of these cofactors is very effective for some patients with subtypes of PDHC deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin supplementation is part of the treatment for PDHC deficiency, and therefore, it should not be avoided. The PDHC reaction requires several cofactors including flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which is generated from riboflavin. Stimulation of residual PDHC via supplementation of these cofactors is very effective for some patients with subtypes of PDHC deficiency.
questions.hint: The patient has pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency (PDHC) manifesting in growth retardation and neurological deficits. The patient's symptoms are likely to improve with a ketogenic diet but worsen with glucose-rich foods or glucogenic amino acids.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of nausea and vomiting for 1 day. His maternal uncle had a seizure disorder and died in childhood. He appears fatigued. Respirations are 32/min. Examination shows diffuse weakness in the extremities. Serum studies show a low pH, elevated lactate concentration, and normal blood glucose. A metabolic condition characterized by a defect in oxidative phosphorylation is suspected. Microscopic examination of a muscle biopsy specimen of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers can be seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and Becker muscular dystrophy. These X-linked disorders most commonly occur in boys 2â€“5 years of age but are caused by a defect in the dystrophin gene, not in oxidative phosphorylation. Early manifestations typically include paresis and atrophy of the proximal lower limbs. Lactic acidosis is not associated with muscular dystrophies.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of muscle tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

There is considerable variability in the size of each muscle fiber due to progressive destruction and fibrosis of the myofibres. Many fibroblasts are visible interspersed between the muscle cells and a large necrotic muscle fiber is seen at the left of the image. Much of the normal contractile muscle fibres have been replaced by hypertrophic connective and adipose tissue.

These are characteristic histological features of muscular dystrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Muscle atrophy with perimysial inflammation is seen in dermatomyositis, which results from a CD4+ T cell-mediated immunologic response, not from defective oxidative phosphorylation. Dermatomyositis manifests with muscle weakness, as in this patient, but is typically limited to proximal muscles (most commonly the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles). Serum studies show elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (creatinine kinase), but lactic acidosis is not associated with the condition. Moreover, this patient does not have characteristic cutaneous manifestations such as heliotrope rash and/or Gottron papules.
Image Description:

Histological section of muscle from the upper thigh (H&E stain)

In addition to the normal musculature, the following pathological findings are visible: pronounced interstitial (green overlay) and perivascular lymphocytic infiltration (V = vessel), muscle fiber necrosis and resorption (green arrow), and perifascicular atrophy (green hatched area), which is characteristic of dermatomyositis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is characteristic of McArdle disease, a disorder in which the muscle is unable to break down glycogen. It commonly manifests in adolescence or early adulthood with muscle cramps, weakness, and myoglobinuria following exercise. Due to the lack of myophosphorylase, affected patients show a flat increase in lactate level during exercise testing, unlike the elevated lactate levels in this patient. Oxidative phosphorylation is unaffected by McArdle disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T-cell infiltration is a typical finding in polymyositis (PM), which is presumably caused by an autoimmune reaction against skeletal muscle antigens, not by defective oxidative phosphorylation. PM presents with muscle weakness, as in this patient, but is typically limited to proximal muscles (most commonly the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles). Serum studies show elevated inflammatory markers and muscle enzymes, but lactate acidosis is not associated with PM.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's lactic acidosis and diffuse muscle weakness in combination with the family history of CNS disease and childhood death suggest a form of mitochondrial myopathy, most likely MELAS syndrome. Subsarcolemmal and intermyofibrillar accumulation of mitochondria in muscle fibers is a hallmark of mitochondrial diseases, which are characterized by defective oxidative phosphorylation and subsequent lack of energy. The compensatory proliferation of mitochondria presents as characteristic ragged-red fibers on Gomori trichrome stain.
questions.hint: This patient's diffuse muscle weakness and lactic acidosis are most likely due to a maternally inherited condition.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain and irritability since delivery. He is at the 10th percentile for height and below the 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
24.2 pg/cell


Mean corpuscular volume
108 Î¼m3


Serum



Ammonia

26 Î¼mol/L (N=11â€“35 Î¼mol/L)


A peripheral blood smear shows macrocytosis of erythrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Supplementation with folate and cobalamin is begun. Two months later, his hemoglobin concentration is 11.1 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 107 Î¼m3. The patient's condition is most likely caused by failure of which of the following enzymatic reactions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The conversion of ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline is facilitated by ornithine transcarbamylase. Individuals deficient in this enzyme typically become symptomatic within 48 hours of birth. Manifestations of hyperammonemia including somnolence, poor feeding, lethargy, and vomiting are typical. However, this patient is already 2 months old and does not have the expected neurological findings. Moreover, macrocytic anemia. as seen in this patient, would not be expected.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

The conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconate is disrupted in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. Typically, the condition first manifests as an episode of jaundice after exposure to a trigger, such as an oxidative drug (e.g., sulfamethoxazole) or eating fava beans. Complete blood count would be consistent with hemolytic anemia (low hemoglobin, normal mean corpuscular volume, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia). Macrocytic anemia would not be an expected manifestation of this condition.
Image Description:

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate conversion is catalyzed by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate transferase (HGPRT). Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Children with this condition often develop megaloblastic anemia, which is seen here. However, most patients are asymptomatic for the first 6 months of life and development and growth are normal. In addition, children typically develop hyperuricemia in the early days of life (which often manifests as orange, sand-like crystals visible in the stool) and, later, self-injurious behavior (a hallmark of this condition) and neurological abnormalities (e.g., intellectual disability, hypotonia), none of which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate is catalyzed by pyruvate kinase. Pyruvate kinase deficiency prevents erythrocytes from producing sufficient ATP, which results in fragile cells that easily lyse. This condition typically manifests with jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly in neonates and continues as a chronic hemolytic anemia of varying severity. Laboratory values would show normocytic anemia with hyperbilirubinemia, not the macrocytic anemia seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and is the metabolic pathway in which glucose is broken down into two pyruvate molecules, generating two molecules of ATP in the process (four ATP generated minus two ATP consumed). In the first phase of glycolysis, ATP (energy) is consumed. In the second and third phases, ATP and reducing equivalents (NADH) are generated.

Black boxes: reactants/products
Blue text: enzymes
Green text: electron carriers (NAD+, NADH+H+) or nucleotides (ATP, ADP) involved in energy consumption and production
Red text: energy (ATP) that is consumed (-) or produced (+) and reducing equivalents (NADH+H+) of each phase

E) CORRECT:

Orotate to uridine 5'-monophosphate conversion is catalyzed by uridine monophosphate synthase, which is the deficient enzyme in orotic aciduria. This condition classically manifests in an infant with failure to thrive and megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to folate and vitamin B12 supplementation. Treatment consists of oral uridine administration to bypass this defect in the de novo pyrimidine pathway.
questions.hint: Megaloblastic anemia (RBC macrocytosis, hypersegmented neutrophils) is a sign of impaired cell division of blood cell precursors in the bone marrow, which may result from inadequate synthesis of nucleic acid. This patient's anemia is refractory to treatment with folate and vitamin B12 (cobalamin), the two most common causes of megaloblastic anemia, which should raise suspicion for a particular autosomal recessive disorder of nucleic acid metabolism.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 1-month history of abnormal movements of her muscles that she cannot control. She has a younger brother with cognitive disabilities and epilepsy. Examination shows frequent, brief, involuntary contractions of the muscle groups of the upper arms, legs, and face that can be triggered by touch. An EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. A trichrome stain of a skeletal muscle biopsy specimen shows muscle fibers with peripheral red inclusions that disrupt the normal fiber contour. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Mutation of the methyl-CpG binding protein 2 gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion of the dystrophia myotonica protein kinase gene (DMPK gene) results in myotonic dystrophy type 1. This condition typically manifests with muscle weakness but also causes myotonia, cataracts, arrhythmias, and primary hypogonadism. It does not cause myoclonus or generalized epilepsy. In addition, biopsy shows atrophic muscle fibers with pyknotic nuclear material, necrosis, and regions of regeneration, not peripheral red inclusions that disrupt the normal fiber contour.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the methyl-CpG binding protein 2 gene (MECP2 gene) results in Rett syndrome. This condition causes myoclonus, ataxia, and seizures but typically manifests by 7â€“24 months of age. In addition, Rett syndrome also causes regression of speech, motor, and cognitive abilities and stereotyped hand-wringing movements, which this patient does not have.

C) CORRECT:

Defective oxidative phosphorylation occurs in patients with myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF) due to point mutations in mitochondrial DNA that result in dysfunction of proteins in the electron transport chain. Like other conditions that follow mitochondrial inheritance, MERRF has variable expression within families due to heteroplasmy. As a result, some patients with MERRF are asymptomatic. Other patients develop symptoms in early childhood (as seen in this patient's brother), or adolescence (as seen in this patient).
Image Description:

Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune endomysial destruction is the underlying cause of polymyositis. This condition typically manifests with symmetric proximal muscle weakness but does not cause myoclonus or generalized epilepsy. In addition, biopsy shows muscle fiber necrosis, regions of degeneration and regeneration, and intrafascicular infiltrates of cytotoxic CD8+ T cells that invade muscle fibers, not peripheral red inclusions that disrupt the normal fiber contour.

E) INCORRECT:

Truncated or absent dystrophin protein results in progressive damage to muscle fibers and is the underlying cause of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. This condition typically manifests by 2â€“5 years of age with muscle weakness of the proximal lower limbs that progresses to involve more distal sites and the upper body. It does not cause myoclonus or generalized epilepsy. In addition, biopsy shows replacement of muscle fibers with fat and connective tissue, not peripheral red inclusions that disrupt the normal fiber contour.
questions.hint: This girl and her brother have myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers, a hereditary condition that causes myoclonus, ataxia, weakness, and generalized epilepsy. Muscle fibers with red inclusions that disrupt the normal fiber contour result in the characteristic ragged appearance seen on histopathologic examination.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of walking difficulties. His mother says that he cannot walk unless he is supported. She has also noted orange, sandy residues in his diapers. Over the past year, she has frequently caught him pulling his toenails and chewing the tips of his fingers. Examination shows scarring of his fingertips. Muscle tone is decreased in the upper and lower extremities. He cannot pick up and hold small objects between the tips of the index finger and the thumb. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition inhibits which of the following conversions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate (IMP) is a step in the purine salvage pathway that can be competitively inhibited by 6-mercaptopurine, a purine analog used as an immunosuppressant drug. However, in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, the conversion of hypoxanthine to IMP is already impaired due to the deficiency of the catalyzing enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. Further pharmacological inhibition of this reaction would counterproductively worsen the disease.
Image Description:

The salvage pathway is the pathway along which purine nucleotides are recycled (adenine, guanine, and hypoxanthine) and reconverted to nucleotides through phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP)-dependent reactions. The enzymes involved in the purine salvage pathway are adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) and hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Both enzymes are inhibited by their end products.

B) INCORRECT:

The conversion of ornithine to citrulline is catalyzed by ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC). OTC deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder and may cause developmental delay and orange, sandy residues in the diapers (due to orotic acid crystals in the urine). However, OTC deficiency does not cause self-mutilating behavior; instead, it is associated with nausea, vomiting, irritability, poor feeding, and in severe cases metabolic encephalopathy, none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, there are currently no clinically-approved OTC inhibitors and further inhibition of the enzyme would worsen the disease.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

The conversion of orotate to uridine monophosphate (UMP) is catalyzed by UMP synthase. A defect in this enzyme leads to accumulation of orotic acid in the serum and urine and a defective de novo synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides. Orotic aciduria may present with developmental delay and orange, sandy residues in the diapers (due to orotic acid crystals in the urine). However, this condition does not manifest with self-mutilating behavior; instead, it is associated with failure to thrive, which is not present in this patient. Furthermore, there are currently no clinically-approved UMP synthase inhibitors and inhibition of the defective enzyme would worsen the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

The conversion of urate to allantoin is catalyzed (not inhibited) by rasburicase, a drug most commonly used in the prevention and treatment of hyperuricemia in the setting of tumor lysis syndrome. Although rasburicase could theoretically be used to treat hyperuricemia secondary to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, the paucity of clinical data supporting its efficacy makes it a less appropriate option. In addition, a drug that inhibits the conversion of urate to allantoin would decrease uric acid excretion and worsen this patient's hyperuricemia.

E) INCORRECT:

The conversion of adenosine (and deoxyadenosine) to inosine is catalyzed by adenosine deaminase. Accumulation of deoxyadenosine due to adenosine deaminase deficiency results in lymphocyte toxicity and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is not associated with delayed motor skills, self-mutilating behavior, or hyperuricemia. Rather, features of SCID include severe recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and fatality in the first year of life if left untreated, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, there are currently no clinically-approved adenosine deaminase inhibitors and inhibition of the already deficient enzyme would worsen the disease.

F) CORRECT:

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors such as allopurinol (first-line choice) or febuxostat (second-line) inhibit the conversion of both hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to urate and are used to treat hyperuricemia in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a congenital deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), a purine salvage enzyme that converts hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanine monophosphate. HGPRT deficiency results in the accumulation of hypoxanthine and guanine, both of which are converted to xanthine and subsequently uric acid.
Image Description:

Acute gout attack: Increases in uric acid concentration or decreases in temperature/pH can lead to the accumulation of urate crystals in various tissues, triggering inflammation. First-line treatment options include NSAIDs, glucocorticoids, and colchicine.

Purine metabolism: Uric acid concentration can increase due to underexcretion (e.g., in chronic renal insufficiency) or over-production (e.g., in tumor lysis syndrome or high dietary purine intake). Xanthine oxidase inhibitors (e.g., allopurinol) inhibit the purine degradation pathway from hypoxanthine to uric acid. Uricosuric medications (e.g., probenecid) inhibit uric acid reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules, thus increasing renal excretion. Pegloticase (a recombinant uricase) catalyzes the breakdown of uric acid into allantoin, which is more water-soluble and, therefore, more readily excreted renally.
questions.hint: This patient's delayed motor skills, self-mutilating behavior, and evidence of hyperuricemia (orange, sand-like sodium urate crystals in his diaper) are consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of intellectual and behavioral abnormalities and abnormal movements of his extremities. His mother reports that he often hits his head and limbs against furniture. He is unable to walk without support and speaks in unclear 2-word phrases. Examination shows multiple bruises on the forehead and several healing wounds over the fingers. There is increased muscle tone in all extremities. Laboratory studies show an increased serum uric acid concentration. The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to also be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine concentrations are increased in patients with defects in phenylalanine hydroxylase, which causes phenylketonuria (PKU). Although this condition can cause intellectual abnormalities and abnormal movements due to seizures, it does not cause hyperuricemia or self-injurious behavior. Instead, other features, such as growth retardation, dermatitis, or a musty body odor, would be reported. Phenylalanine concentrations are normal in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Orotic acid concentrations are increased in patients with uridine monophosphate synthase deficiency (orotic aciduria) or ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Orotic aciduria can cause developmental delay, but it does not cause motor symptoms, self-injurious behavior, or hyperuricemia. OTC deficiency would cause features of hyperammonemia (e.g., vomiting, somnolence, asterixis). Orotic acid concentrations are normal in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

Adenosine monophosphate and its derivates such as deoxyadenosine triphosphate (dATP) accumulate in patients with adenosine deaminase deficiency, which causes severe combined immunodeficiency. This condition manifests with failure to thrive and severe, recurrent infections in the first year of life. Deoxyadenosine trisphosphate does not accumulate in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:
