Branched-chain amino acids (isoleucine, leucine, and valine) accumulate in patients with maple syrup urine disease, which manifests during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, ketonuria, and sweet-smelling urine. Branched-chain amino acids do not accumulate in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
Image Description:

There are 20 proteinogenic amino acids, which can be classified according to the physical properties of their side chains (polarity, charge). The amino acids with aromatic side chains appear in red here, while the branched-chain amino acids are in blue. Polar, uncharged amino acids include the three amino acids with a hydroxyl group on their side chain, serine, threonine, and tyrosine, which often undergo post-translational modification (phosphorylation), as well as the two derivates of positively charged amino acids aspartate and glutamate, asparagine and glutamine, both of which have a carboxamide group on their side chain.

E) CORRECT:

Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) is a substrate in the purine salvage pathway that accumulates in patients who have HGPRT deficiency. The inability to regenerate purine nucleotides also leads to an excess of guanine and hypoxanthine bases, which are instead metabolized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, leading to hyperuricemia. The hyperuricemia seen in patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome can be treated by inhibiting xanthine oxidase with allopurinol or febuxostat, but this does not affect the neurological or behavioral features of this condition.
Image Description:

Purine nucleotides are degraded in several steps into uric acid, which is excreted in the urine.

Purine nucleotides (e.g., AMP, IMP, XMP, and GMP) are converted into purine nucleosides. This conversion occurs through hydrolytic cleavage of the phosphate residue and is catalyzed by nucleotidases.

Purine nucleosides are then cleaved into free bases (e.g., hypoxanthine, xanthine, and guanine) by nucleoside phosphorylases.

Xanthine is then oxidized to uric acid by xanthine oxidase, the uric acid is partially reabsorbed, and the rest is excreted in the urine.

F) INCORRECT:

Cytosine monophosphate is a pyrimidine nucleotide. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by defects in the purine salvage pathway and results in increased de novo purine synthesis; it does not increase the production of pyrimidines.
questions.hint: This boy has Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an X-linked recessive condition caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) that manifests with hyperuricemia, spasticity, dystonia, developmental delay, and self-injurious behavior.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for sudden-onset slurring of speech and weakness of her right arm and leg. She has a mild intellectual disability. She is at the 10th percentile for weight and at the 85th percentile for height. Physical examination shows bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens and a high-arched palate. Her fingers are long and slender. Neurological examination shows an extensor plantar response on the right. This patient is most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supplementation of methionine is the treatment of choice for homocystinuria caused by defective methionine synthase. However, it is a rare cause of homocystinuria, and symptoms typically present earlier and more acutely. In all other forms of homocystinuria, methionine intake should be restricted in order to prevent further accumulation of homocysteine.

B) INCORRECT:

Together with tyrosine supplementation, dietary restriction of phenylalanine is the treatment of choice for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU). Although PKU does present with intellectual disabilities, which are seen in this patient, it is not associated with marfanoid habitus, lens luxation, or vascular events. Moreover, patients with PKU typically have a history of seizures and skin disorders such as eczema and may have a characteristic musty body odor.

C) INCORRECT:

Alkalinization of the urine to a pH > 7 through the administration of potassium citrate or potassium bicarbonate dissolves cystine stones formed in cystinuria. However, homocystinuria does not lead to the formation of cystine stones, and patients would not benefit from such a treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Vitamin B6 is a cofactor of cystathionine synthase, which catalyzes the first step of conversion of homocysteine and serine into cystathionine. Homocystinuria caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of the enzyme for vitamin B6 can be treated with B6 supplementation. However, only about 50% of patients are pyridoxine-responsive. Because cystathionine synthase deficiency results in the accumulation of thrombogenic homocysteine, it predisposes to thromboembolic events (e.g., acute stroke). Lowering the plasma homocysteine concentration is therefore the single most important factor for reducing the risk of vascular events.

E) INCORRECT:

Homocystinuria is most commonly caused by defective conversion of homocysteine to cysteine. Subsequently, cysteine levels are usually decreased and supplementation is indicated, not restriction.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of an acute stroke (hemiplegia, slurred speech, positive Babinski sign), Marfanoid habitus (tall stature, high-arched palate, arachnodactyly), inferonasal lens subluxation, and intellectual disability, indicating homocystinuria most likely caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 30 minutes after having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He was born at home and has not attended any well-child visits. He is not yet able to walk and does not use recognizable words. His paternal uncle has a severe intellectual disability and has been living in an assisted-living facility all of his life. The boy's urine phenylacetate level is markedly elevated. Which of the following amino acids is most likely nutritionally essential for this patient because of his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid in humans. However, management of phenylketonuria, a condition characterized by excess levels of phenylalanine and its metabolites, involves dietary restriction of this protein. Supplementation of phenylalanine would worsen this patient's clinical condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Glutamate is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from Î±-ketoglutarate via the action of glutamate dehydrogenase and from glutamine via glutaminase. Glutamate synthesis is not affected in patients with PKU.

C) INCORRECT:

Alanine is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from pyruvate via the action of alanine aminotransferase. Synthesis of this amino acid is not affected in patients with PKU.

D) CORRECT:

Tyrosine is nutritionally essential to patients with PKU and must be supplemented. Phenylalanine hydroxylase normally converts phenylalanine into tyrosine, but this enzyme is lacking in classic phenylketonuria. The seizure seen in this patient was caused by insufficient tyrosine, which is necessary for neurotransmitter and thyroxine production. Tyrosine is also required for melanin production, explaining the light skin characteristic of PKU. Other symptoms include a musty body odor, failure to thrive, loss of motor control, and mental disabilities.

E) INCORRECT:

Arginine is a conditionally essential amino acid that can be synthesized from citrulline via the action of argininosuccinate synthetase and argininosuccinate lyase (in the urea cycle). Arginine can become essential during times of increased demand (e.g., growth phases during childhood). However, synthesis pathways of this amino acid are not affected in patients with PKU.

F) INCORRECT:

Cysteine is a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from homocysteine and serine via the action of cystathionine synthase. Synthesis pathways of this amino acid are not affected in patients with PKU.
questions.hint: This patient's seizure, speech and motor delays, and elevated urine phenylacetate are indicative of phenylketonuria (PKU). His family history of severe intellectual disability, the hallmark of untreated PKU, is consistent with the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of this condition.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician after his adoptive mother observed jerking movements of his arms and legs earlier that morning. He was adopted from an orphanage in Albania at 4 months of age. He has a history of intellectual disability. Examination shows pale skin and light blue eyes. There is a dry, eczematous, scaly rash on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. This patient is most likely deficient in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in failure to convert phenylalanine to tyrosine and is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria (PKU). Symptoms usually develop after the neonatal period and include developmental delay and seizures (due to phenylalanine accumulation in the CNS), hypopigmentation (due to a lack of melanin production from low levels of tyrosine), and eczema, all of which are present in this case. In addition, PKU manifests with a characteristic mousy or musty odor due to excretion of phenylalanine metabolites in the urine and sweat. PKU is typically detected by newborn screening for metabolic disorders.

B) INCORRECT:

Branched-chain Î±-ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency results in the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., valine, leucine, isoleucine) and causes maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). This condition manifests in the early neonatal period with vomiting, lethargy, dystonia, hypoglycemia (which can lead to seizures), and a characteristic maple syrup odor to the urine which eventually lead to severe central nervous system defects and intellectual disability.

C) INCORRECT:

Cystathionine synthase deficiency leads to homocystinuria, which can cause intellectual disability and seizures. However, this condition also causes ectopia lentis, marfanoid habitus, and increased risk of thrombosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency can cause intellectual disability and seizures. However, this condition typically manifests shortly after birth, not in early childhood. In addition, OTC deficiency causes symptoms of hyperammonemia (e.g., asterixis, slurred speech, nausea, vomiting, irritability).

E) INCORRECT:

Tyrosinase deficiency leads to oculocutaneous albinism due to defective melanin production and causes pale skin and light-colored eyes. However, this condition also typically manifests with visual abnormalities.

F) INCORRECT:

Homogentisate oxidase deficiency causes alkaptonuria. This condition results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which leads to ochronosis, valvular calcification, and nephrolithiasis. The urine of patients with alkaptonuria turns dark brown/black when left standing or alkalinized. Unlike this patient, affected individuals are typically asymptomatic in childhood.
questions.hint: This boy has an autosomal recessive condition that, in addition to the symptoms above, also causes a characteristic mousy or musty odor of the body and urine.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy whose family recently emigrated from Bangladesh is brought to the physician by his mother because of failure to thrive. He is below the 5th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows truncal hypotonia and rigidity of the lower extremities. He is unable to pick his head up while laying on his stomach or sit upright on his own. He has light skin and pale blue eyes. Laboratory studies show decreased activity of dihydropteridine reductase in erythrocytes. Analysis of this patient's cerebrospinal fluid is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

THB serves as a cofactor for tryptophan hydroxylase, which catalyzes the first step in the conversion of tryptophan to serotonin. Consequently, THB deficiency leads to a decreased serotonin concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolactin release is inhibited by a hormone whose synthesis is dependent on THB as a cofactor. Consequently, THB deficiency leads to an increased prolactin concentration due to a decreased concentration of its release-inhibiting hormone.

C) CORRECT:

Tetrahydrobiopterin (THB) serves as a cofactor for the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase. Consequently, this patient's THB deficiency results in a decreased DOPA concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid. Because DOPA is a precursor of dopamine and norepinephrine, the production of these neurotransmitters decreases, which leads to hypotonia and progressive neurologic deterioration. Because DOPA is a precursor for melanin synthesis, THB deficiency results in light skin and blue eyes. THB is also required for the synthesis of serotonin, which is required for the production of melatonin. Immediate treatment with supplementation of THB, levodopa/carbidopa, and serotonin can prevent further compromise of this patient's development.

THB deficiency has manifestations similar to those of phenylketonuria (PKU) because THB is required for the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine by phenylalanine hydroxylase. These conditions can be distinguished from another with an oral THB loading test. After oral loading, phenylalanine concentrations decrease in patients with THB deficiency and remain unchanged in patients with PKU.
Image Description:

Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

D) INCORRECT:

THB serves as a cofactor for nitric oxide synthase, which converts arginine to nitric oxide and citrulline using NADPH and O2. Consequently, THB deficiency leads to a decreased nitric oxide concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.

E) INCORRECT:

THB serves as a cofactor for the first two steps of norepinephrine synthesis. Consequently, THB deficiency leads to a decreased norepinephrine concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.
questions.hint: Dihydropteridine reductase converts dihydrobiopterin to tetrahydrobiopterin (THB), which serves as an important cofactor in several enzymatic reactions of amino acid metabolism.

questions.text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician because of somnolence, poor feeding, and vomiting after his first few breast feedings. He appears lethargic. His respiratory rate is 73/min. Serum ammonia is markedly increased. Genetic analysis shows deficiency in N-acetylglutamate synthase. The activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely directly affected by this genetic defect?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

N-acetylglutamate increases the activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1), a mitochondrial enzyme that converts bicarbonate and ammonia to carbamoyl phosphate using 2 molecules of ATP. This process is the rate-limiting step of the urea cycle. N-acetylglutamate is synthesized primarily in the liver and small intestinal cells when the cellular concentration of arginine is increased. In this way, the activity of CPS1 is increased following a protein-rich meal, when ammonia production is expected to be increased.

The two most common hereditary defects in the urea cycle are ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency) and CPS1 deficiency. Neonates with either of these defects are usually normal at birth but present with vomiting, lethargy, hyperventilation, and cerebral edema (due to intracellular accumulation of glutamine) after the first 24â€“72 hours as a result of introduction of dietary protein. In addition to increased ammonia levels in blood, they have increased glutamine and decreased blood urea nitrogen. OTC deficiency can be differentiated from CPS1 deficiency by the presence of orotic acid in urine.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

B) INCORRECT:

Ornithine translocase is a mitochondrial protein that is critical for urea cycle activity because it transports ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria, where it is converted to citrulline by ornithine transcarbamylase. A defect in ornithine translocase would cause hyperammonemia, but this protein's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase is a mitochondrial enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it transfers a carbamoyl group onto ornithine to form citrulline. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinate synthetase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it synthesizes argininosuccinate from aspartate and citrulline. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Argininosuccinase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it converts arginosuccinate to arginine and fumarate. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia, but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Arginase is a cytoplasmic enzyme that is critical for urea cycle activity because it converts arginine to urea and ornithine. A deficiency of this enzyme would cause hyperammonemia but this enzyme's activity is not affected by N-acetylglutamate levels.
questions.hint: N-acetylglutamate synthase produces N-acetylglutamate, which serves as an allosteric activator for one of the two enzymatic reactions of the urea cycle that take place in the mitochondria.

questions.text: A 3-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of somnolence, poor feeding, and one episode of vomiting. He is exclusively breastfed. His serum glucose concentration is 88 mg/dL and his serum ammonia concentration is 850 Î¼mol/L (N<90). Urinalysis shows an increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio. Urinary ketones are absent. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following reactions?

choices.text: Hypoxanthine and phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate to inosine monophosphate
Ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline
Glutamate and acetyl-coenzyme A to N-acetylglutamate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The production of inosine monophosphate from hypoxanthine and phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate is catalyzed by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) in the purine salvage pathway. Deficiency of HGPRT causes Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is marked by uric aciduria but not hyperammonemia. Additionally, Lesch Nyhan syndrome usually manifests after 6 months of life, making it an unlikely cause of this 3-day old's symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Citrulline production from ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate is a reaction in the urea cycle catalyzed by ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC). OTC deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder. It causes a buildup of ammonia and carbamoyl phosphate, which is converted to orotic acid. This patient's orotic aciduria and hyperammonemia make OTC deficiency the most likely diagnosis. Affected individuals usually present in infancy or early childhood and typically become symptomatic after beginning to nurse or bottle feed. Both breast milk and formula contain amino acids that would normally be broken down in the urea cycle.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

The conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate is catalyzed by uridine monophosphate synthase. Deficiency of uridine monophosphate synthase results in buildup of orotic acid, which would explain this patient's orotic aciduria. However, it does not explain this patient's hyperammonemia, since ammonia can still be eliminated via the urea cycle without uridine monophosphate synthase.

D) INCORRECT:

The conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-coA is catalyzed by pyruvate dehydrogenase, which connects the glycolysis pathway with the citric acid cycle. Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency does manifest in neonates and may have an element of hyperammonemia. However, it does not cause orotic aciduria. Key laboratory findings in pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency include severe lactic acidosis, high serum pyruvate, and high serum and urine alanine.

E) INCORRECT:

The conversion of glutamate and acetyl-coA to N-acetylglutamate is catalyzed by N-acetylglutamate synthase. Deficiency of this enzyme results in insufficient N-acetylglutamate, a cofactor required by carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I to produce carbamoyl phosphate for the urea cycle. Although N-acetylglutamate synthase deficiency manifests in neonates with hyperammonemia, it would not explain this patient's orotic aciduria.

F) INCORRECT:

The breakdown of arginine into urea and ornithine is catalyzed by arginase, an enzyme in the urea cycle. Arginase deficiency only causes mild hyperammonemia and rarely causes orotic aciduria. Additionally, symptoms of arginase deficiency are more neurologic in nature (including spasticity, dystonia, and ataxia) and typically manifest in late childhood, unlike this neonate with somnolence and vomiting.
questions.hint: Orotic acid is an intermediary in the pyrimidine biosynthetic pathway, which is connected to the urea cycle via a common intermediate.

questions.text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Physical examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. He appears lethargic. His diapers emit a caramel-like odor. Urine studies are positive for ketone bodies. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by decreased activity of branched-chain Î±-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH). Supplementation of thiamine (vitamin B1), which is a cofactor for several dehydrogenases, can increase the activity of BCKDH in some patients with MSUD (thiamine-responsive MSUD). In addition to thiamine supplementation, patients should avoid intake of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., isoleucine, leucine, and valine).

B) INCORRECT:

Cysteine supplementation is indicated for patients with homocystinuria due to cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate. Patients with homocystinuria are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period but can develop osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease, and/or intellectual disability as they grow older. Urinalysis of patients with homocystinuria shows increased homocysteine levels, not ketone bodies. Cysteine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased intake of ketogenic amino acids (e.g., leucine, lysine) is indicated for patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency (PDCD), which can manifest in the neonatal period with vomiting, irritability, dystonia, and lethargy. However, this condition does not cause a caramel-like odor to the urine or ketonuria. In addition, PDCD results in decreased acetyl-CoA production and thus decreased ketone body synthesis. This patient with maple syrup urine disease should avoid intake of leucine, which is a branched-chain amino acid.

D) INCORRECT:

Methionine supplementation is indicated for patients with homocystinuria due to methionine synthase deficiency. Patients with homocystinuria are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period but can develop osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease, and/or intellectual disability as they grow older. Urinalysis of patients with homocystinuria shows increased homocysteine levels, not ketone bodies. Methionine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine supplementation is indicated for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which can manifest with poor feeding, lethargy, spasticity due to CNS damage, and ketonuria. However, patients with PKU are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period. In addition, the urine of patients with PKU typically has a musty odor, not a caramel-like odor. Tyrosine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) supplementation is indicated for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which can manifest with poor feeding, lethargy, spasticity due to CNS damage, and ketonuria. However, patients with PKU are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period. In addition, the urine of patients with PKU typically has a musty odor, not a caramel-like odor. BH4 supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.
questions.hint: This boy has maple syrup urine disease, which typically manifests in the early neonatal period with vomiting, irritability, poor feeding, dystonia, lethargy, urine that has a sweet-smelling odor, and ketonuria.

questions.text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of vomiting. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 5th percentile for length and weight. Physical examination shows generalized hypotonia. Urinalysis shows increased propionic acid concentration. The finding on urinalysis is best explained by the breakdown of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids can generate both acetyl-CoA and propionyl-CoA (propionic acid coupled with coenzyme A), but the breakdown of even-chain fatty acids only produces acetyl-CoA. Accumulation of acetyl-CoA would lead to increased generation of ketoacids (e.g., acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate) and ketoaciduria.
Image Description:

Acetyl-CoA is metabolized within hepatocytes to produce ketone bodies (i.e., acetoacetate and Î²-hydroxybutyrate) through the process of ketogenesis. The lack of thiophorase in hepatocytes prevents the consumption of ketone bodies within the liver. During states of ketosis, excess acetoacetate undergoes spontaneous decarboxylation into acetone, a volatile organic acid that can be eliminated through the respiratory system.

B) INCORRECT:

Examples of hexose monosaccharides include glucose, fructose, and galactose. Catabolism of glucose and galactose by aldose reductase can form sorbitol and galactitol, respectively. Galactitol can accumulate in newborns with galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency and cause lethargy, vomiting, failure to thrive, and generalized hypotonia. However, urinalysis would show reducing substances, not propionic acid. Propionic acid is not generated during the metabolism of hexoses but can serve as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

C) CORRECT:

Propionyl-CoA is generated by the catabolism of the amino acids threonine, methionine, isoleucine, and valine. Of these amino acids, isoleucine and valine are branched-chain amino acids. Propionyl-CoA is also generated by the catabolism of odd-chain fatty acids, cholesterol, and the pyrimidines thymine and uracil. Propionyl-CoA carboxylase converts propionyl-CoA to methylmalonyl-CoA, which is converted to succinyl-CoA by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase. Succinyl-CoA generates oxaloacetate via the TCA cycle, which can be used to generate glucose (gluconeogenesis). A deficiency of propionyl-CoA carboxylase or methylmalonyl-CoA mutase can, therefore, cause symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., muscular hypotonia, vomiting, and lethargy), failure to thrive, and HAGMA due to the accumulation of propionic acid, which is subsequently excreted in urine.
Image Description:

The amino acids methionine, isoleucine, valine, and threonine are metabolized to succinyl-CoA via propionyl-CoA and methylmalonyl-CoA. Succinyl-CoA is introduced into the citric acid cycle and can, when required, enter into gluconeogenesis via oxaloacetate.

D) INCORRECT:

Metabolism of catechol-containing monoamines (catecholamines) produces vanillylmandelic acid, homovanillic acid, and metanephrines, which are readily detectable in the urine. These are seen in conditions with that cause abnormally high catecholamine production such as pheochromocytoma and neuroblastoma. Propionic acid is not formed during the process of catecholamine catabolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Purines (e.g., adenine, guanine) are bicyclic nitrogenous bases. The catabolism of purines leads to the formation of uric acid, not propionic acid. Catabolism of certain pyrimidines such as thymine and uracil can produce propionyl-CoA (propionic acid coupled with coenzyme A), but pyrimidines are monocyclic nitrogenous bases.
Image Description:

The bases of the nucleic acids DNA and RNA are derivatives of purine and pyrimidine. DNA consists of the purine bases adenine and guanine and the pyrimidine bases cytosine and thymine. RNA contains the pyrimidine base uracil instead of thymine, with the remaining three bases being the same as those found in DNA. Purine bases also include hypoxanthine and xanthine, which are not DNA components, but represent intermediate products of purine base degradation.
questions.hint: The failure of the breakdown of this substance can result in maple syrup urine disease.

questions.text: A 1-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after having a seizure. His mother reports that he has become lethargic and does not cry as vigorously anymore. Examination shows muscular hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Arterial blood gas on room air shows metabolic acidosis. Serum studies show elevated levels of methylmalonic acid. A deficiency of which of the following types of enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dehydrogenase enzymes catalyze redox reactions. Common diseases of dehydrogenases include maple syrup urine disease (branched-chain Î±-ketoacid dehydrogenase), pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, lactate dehydrogenase deficiency, and medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Dehydrogenases are not involved in methylmalonyl-CoA conversion.

B) INCORRECT:

Phosphorylase enzymes are crucial to several carbohydrate metabolic pathways where they aid in glycogenolysis by adding inorganic phosphate groups onto their substrates. When deficient (e.g., McArdle disease, Hers disease), affected patients may present with muscle weakness, hypoglycemia, exercise intolerance, hepatomegaly (as seen in this patient), or rhabdomyolysis. However, serum studies will not show any evidence of methylmalonic acidemia as phosphorylase enzymes do not participate in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

C) INCORRECT:

Methionine synthase deficiency will present with elevated serum levels of homocysteine (absent in this patient) and methylmalonyl-CoA. A cystathionine synthase deficiency will also result in homocystinuria and affected patients will be clinically similar to patients with a methionine synthase deficiency. Affected patients may present with myopia, ectopia lentis, intellectual disability, skeletal anomalies (resembling Marfan syndrome), and thromboembolic events, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's presentation and serum analysis are more indicative of a different enzyme deficiency that causes methylmalonic acidemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Carboxylase enzymes transfer carbon dioxide groups and require biotin as a cofactor. Notable examples include pyruvate carboxylase (carbohydrate metabolism), acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis), and propionyl-CoA carboxylase (odd-chain fatty acid degradation). Although deficiency of enzymes of this type can lead to organic acidemias, they are not involved in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydroxylase enzymes add a hydroxyl group (âˆ’OH) to their substrate. In the liver, the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. A defect in PAH is the hallmark of phenylketonuria (PKU). Affected patients may present with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, eczema, psychomotor retardation, blue eyes, and light pale hair are more characteristic of PKU. Hydroxylases do not participate in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

F) CORRECT:

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is the enzyme that catalyzes the isomerization of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. A deficiency of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, or its cofactor vitamin B12, will result in accumulation of methylmalonic acid in the serum. Methylmalonic acidemia in neonates typically presents with lethargy, vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and encephalopathy. Affected patients are at risk of severe morbidity if disease is left untreated.
questions.hint: Elevated levels of methylmalonic acid in the presence of metabolic acidosis are suggestive of methylmalonic acidemia, which is most commonly caused by a deficiency of an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her father after he observed jerking movements of her arms and legs earlier in the day. She appears lethargic. Physical examination shows generalized hypotonia. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costophrenic angle. Her fingerstick glucose shows hypoglycemia. Serum levels of acetone, acetoacetate, and Î²-hydroxybutyrate are undetectable. Molecular genetic testing shows a mutation in the carnitine palmitoyltransferase II gene. This patient will most likely benefit from supplementation with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) are transported by the carnitine shuttle into the mitochondrial matrix, where they serve as substrates for Î²-oxidation. In CPT II deficiency, this transport is impaired because CPT II is responsible for removing the LCFA from carnitine inside the mitochondria. Intake of LCFA would worsen this patient's condition rather than improve it.

B) INCORRECT:

Coenzyme A is derived from vitamin B5 and serves as a cofactor for acyl transfers and fatty acid metabolism. However, it plays a role in the synthesis of fatty acids, not in fatty acid breakdown. Also, patients with a vitamin B5 deficiency would have features of adrenal insufficiency, enteritis, alopecia, dermatitis, and distal paresthesia and dysesthesia. Seizures, weakness, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, hypoglycemia, and undetectable ketone concentration would not be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor for reactions catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase, tyrosine hydroxylase, and tryptophan hydroxylase. It is not supplemented in CPA II deficiency but in tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency and phenylketonuria, which can both manifest with seizures. However, lethargy, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, hypoglycemia, and undetectable ketone concentration would not be seen.

D) CORRECT:

CPT II is a mitochondrial enzyme that removes long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) from carnitine once the LCFAs have entered the mitochondria (the attachment to carnitine is required for entry from the cytosol into the mitochondria). In CPT II deficiency, LCFA cannot be metabolized, which leads to hypoketotic hypoglycemia (due to the reduced substrate available for gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis), myalgia, and weakness. Furthermore, the build-up of LCFA in cells leads to hepatomegaly, liver failure, cardiomyopathy, and rhabdomyolysis. In addition to avoiding intake of LCFA, increased intake of medium-chain fatty acids is recommended, as they do not require carnitine transport and therefore can be metabolized despite the CPT II defect.
Image Description:

Substances of energy excess (e.g., glucose, malonyl-CoA, citrate) ultimately inhibit pathways leading to energy production (e.g., beta-oxidation and the citric acid cycle) through activation of several key molecules: Increased levels of insulin and/or citrate â†’ activation of the acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC) enzyme via protein phosphatase 2 (PP2) or directly â†’ formation of malonyl-CoA â†’ inhibition of beta-oxidation within the mitochondria.

Substances of energy deficiency (e.g., glucagon, catecholamines, AMP/ADP) act to increase energy production via the upregulation of AMP-kinase (AMPK). AMPK acts to inactivate the ACC enzyme and promotes energy production via beta-oxidation.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiamine is a water-soluble vitamin and a cofactor for several dehydrogenase enzyme reactions. It is not supplemented in CPA II deficiency but in maple syrup urine disease, which is caused by deficient branched-chain Î±-ketoacid dehydrogenase with subsequent impaired degradation of branched-chain amino acids (valine, leucine, isoleucine). Maple syrup urine disease can also present with hypoglycemia and lethargy. However, this patient lacks the cardinal symptom of sweet-smelling urine (maple syrup odor) and the onset would already be expected in the early neonatal period. Furthermore, hepatomegaly, seizures, and undetectable ketones would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Methionine is a glucogenic, essential amino acid that plays a role in homocysteine metabolism. It is not supplemented in CPA II deficiency but in homocystinuria, which would manifest with seizures. However, it would also result in inferonasal lens dislocation, thrombosis, elongated bones, and intellectual disability. Moreover, weakness, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, hypoglycemia, and a decreased ketone concentration would not be seen.
questions.hint: Seizures, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and hypoketotic hypoglycemia are consistent with the infantile form of carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency (CPT II deficiency), an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder caused by impaired carnitine transport of fatty acids to the mitochondria. The mutation found on molecular testing confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-week old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of lethargy, recurrent vomiting, and poor weight gain since birth. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor and a bulging frontal fontanelle. Serum studies show an ammonia concentration of 170 Î¼mol/L (N < 30) and low serum citrulline levels. The oral intake of which of the following nutrients should be restricted in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fructose intake would have to be restricted in patients with aldolase B deficiency (hereditary fructose intolerance), which can cause hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia and resulting symptoms such as anterior fontanelle bulging (due to increased ICP in hepatic encephalopathy), vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), lethargy, and failure to thrive, as seen in this infant. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus. Furthermore, aldolase B deficiency would not cause low citrulline levels, but rather hypoglycemia.
Image Description:

(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

B) CORRECT:

The urea cycle is responsible for the conversion of toxic nitrogenous waste (NH3) generated from amino acid catabolism to urea, which is then excreted by the kidneys. In individuals with hyperammonemia due to urea cycle disorders or hepatotoxicity, dietary protein restriction can limit the amount of NH3 generated from amino acids.
Image Description:

The urea cycle is a metabolic pathway specific to the liver that converts cytotoxic ammonia into urea for excretion.

In the mitochondrion, ammonia and bicarbonate react to form carbamoyl phosphate, catalyzed by carbamoyl phosphate synthase and requires two ATP molecules. Carbamoyl phosphate then enters the urea cycle by reacting with ornithine to form citrulline. Citrulline is transported via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter into the cytosol. In an ATP-dependent reaction, argininosuccinate synthase condenses citrulline and aspartate to argininosuccinate. Next, argininosuccinate is cleaved into fumarate and arginine, which in turn is cleaved by arginase into urea and ornithine. Ornithine is transported back into the mitochondrion via the ornithine/citrulline antiporter and thus becomes available for reacting with carbamoyl phosphate in a new cycle. Urea is excreted via the kidneys.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic vitamin A toxicity may cause pseudotumor cerebri and hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia. Infants with this condition can, therefore, develop anterior fontanelle bulging, vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), and lethargy, which are also seen here. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus, and vitamin A toxicity would not cause low citrulline levels. Moreover, other features of chronic vitamin A toxicity, such as alopecia and dry skin, would be expected on examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Fatty acid intake would require restriction in patients with medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, which can cause hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia and resulting symptoms such as anterior fontanelle bulging (due to increased ICP in hepatic encephalopathy), vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), lethargy, and failure to thrive, as seen in this infant. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus. Furthermore, MCAD deficiency would not cause low citrulline levels, but rather hypoglycemia and increased fatty acylcarnitine levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Gluten would require restriction in patients with celiac disease, which can cause lethargy and failure to thrive due to malabsorption. However, the symptoms of pediatric celiac disease typically only begin at 9â€“24 months. Furthermore, features such as nausea, vomiting, a bulging anterior fontanelle, decreased skin turgor, hyperammonemia, and low citrulline levels would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Lactose intake would have to be restricted in patients with classic galactosemia, which can cause hepatotoxicity with subsequent hyperammonemia and resulting symptoms such as anterior fontanelle bulging (due to increased ICP in hepatic encephalopathy), vomiting with features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor), lethargy, and failure to thrive, as seen in this infant. However, patients with hyperammonemia due to hepatotoxicity would have icterus. Furthermore, classic galactosemia would not cause low citrulline levels and would likely manifest with infantile cataracts.
questions.hint: Findings of increased serum orotic acid levels would help differentiate between ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency and carbamoyl phosphate synthase 1 deficiency as a cause of this patient's urea cycle disorder.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He has no history of major medical illness. His mother says, â€œSometimes when my son forgets to flush, his urine leaves dark stains in the toilet.â€ She is unconcerned because her son already had dark-colored urine as a baby and he has never had any health issues. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patientâ€™s condition is most likely associated with impaired formation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine due to a deficiency of cystathionine synthase or reduced affinity of this enzyme for pyridoxal phosphate causes homocystinuria. This condition would not manifest with dark-colored urine in an otherwise asymptomatic child. Instead, the accumulation of homocysteine in organ tissues results in features such as early developmental delay and intellectual disability, a marfanoid habitus, downward lens subluxation, and thrombotic events, none of which is seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired conversion of propionyl-CoA to methylmalonate due to a deficiency of propionyl-CoA carboxylase causes propionic acidemia. This condition would not manifest with dark-colored urine in an otherwise asymptomatic child. Instead, the accumulation of propionic acid in organ tissues causes features to appear already in early infancy, e.g., failure to thrive (vomiting, poor feeding), developmental delay, neurological symptoms (e.g., hypotonia, seizures), metabolic acidosis, and hepatomegaly, none of which is seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Alkaptonuria is caused by a defect in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase, which leads to accumulation, not impaired formation, of homogentisate (HGA). Accumulation of HGA in body fluids and organ tissues results in the typical manifestations of this disorder (e.g., urinary discoloration due to oxidation of accumulated HGA).

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine due to a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) causes phenylketonuria (PKU). This condition would not manifest with dark-colored urine in an otherwise asymptomatic child. Instead, PKU typically manifests within the first few months of life with psychomotor delay, seizures, eczema, signs of melanin deficiency (i.e., light skin, pale hair, blue iris), and a musty odor, none of which are seen here. PKU is usually diagnosed during newborn screening.

E) CORRECT:

Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase, an enzyme that converts homogentisate (HGA) to maleylacetoacetate. Affected individuals are usually asymptomatic in childhood but may excrete urine that turns dark if left standing (due to oxidation of accumulated HGA). Eventually, HGA deposition in tissues throughout the body leads to connective tissue discoloration (e.g., bluish-black discoloration of ear cartilage and sclerae) and organ damage, with manifestations such as arthritis, nephrolithiasis, and coronary artery disease. Treatment of alkaptonuria involves a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine, which reduces the formation of HGA.
questions.hint: This patient has alkaptonuria, a condition characterized by the excretion of urine that appears normal when fresh but turns dark after exposure to oxygen.

questions.text: A 1-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of newborn screening showed an increased serum concentration of phenylalanine. Genetic analysis confirms a diagnosis of phenylketonuria. The physician counsels the patient's family on the recommended dietary restrictions, including avoidance of artificial sweeteners that contain aspartame. Aspartame is a molecule composed of aspartate and phenylalanine and its digestion can lead to hyperphenylalaninemia in patients with phenylketonuria. Which of the following enzymes is primarily responsible for the breakdown of aspartame?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pepsin, a gastric endopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds within protein molecules and targets specific peptide bonds between hydrophobic and aromatic amino acids (e.g., phenylalanine-tryptophan). Pepsin does not target peptide bonds involving hydrophilic amino acids such as aspartate. Moreover, aspartame has two terminal amino acids and can only be broken down by an enzyme with exopeptidase activity.

B) CORRECT:

Dipeptidase is a brush border enzyme in the human duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. It is a type of exopeptidase that hydrolyzes dipeptides such as aspartame.
Image Description:

In the stomach, gastric acid denatures dietary proteins, and pepsin cleaves the denatured proteins into peptides of various lengths.

In the duodenum, peptides are cleaved by exopeptidases (proteases that split peptide bonds at terminal ends, e.g. Carboxypeptidase A and B) and endopeptidases (proteases that split peptide bonds within the polypeptide chain, e.g. Trypsin, Chymotrypsin, Elastase).

Oligopeptides are broken down to di-/tripeptides by oligopeptidases at the enterocyte brush border. Some di-/tripeptides are absorbed into the enterocyte via a proton symporter (PepT1), and some remain in the intestinal lumen are broken down to amino acids in the intestinal lumen. Oligopeptides are also broken down to amino acids by aminopeptidases at the enterocyte brush border.

Within the enterocyte, dipeptides/tripeptides that were absorbed by the enterocyte are broken down to single amino acids by dipeptidases/tripeptidases.

Single amino acids within the intestinal lumen are absorbed by the enterocyte via Na+-coupled carrier proteins for specific amino acid groups (e.g. basic, neutral, acidic).

Single amino acids are transported out of the enterocyte (via basolateral transporters) into the bloodstream and travel to the liver via the portal vein.

C) INCORRECT:

Chymotrypsin, a pancreatic endopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds within protein molecules and targets specific peptide bonds between hydrophobic and aromatic amino acids (e.g., phenylalanine-tryptophan). Chymotrypsin does not target peptide bonds involving hydrophilic amino acids such as aspartate. Moreover, aspartame has two terminal amino acids and can only be broken down by an enzyme with exopeptidase activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Trypsin, a pancreatic endopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds within protein molecules and targets specific peptide bonds that contain the positively charged amino acids arginine or lysine. Trypsin does not target peptide bonds involving the hydrophobic amino acid phenylalanine or the negatively charged aspartate. Moreover, aspartame has two terminal amino acids and can only be broken down by an enzyme with exopeptidase activity.

E) INCORRECT:

Carboxypeptidase A, a pancreatic exopeptidase, cleaves peptide bonds at the carboxyterminal end and preferentially targets peptide bonds with aromatic amino acids such as phenylalanine. Aspartame, a dipeptide, has a carboxyterminal phenylalanine residue. However, in dipeptides the rate of peptide bond hydrolysis by carboxypeptidase A is very slow; a different type of exopeptidase is primarily responsible for their breakdown.
questions.hint: Aspartame is primarily cleaved by a brush border enzyme on the villi of the mucosa in the small intestine.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of recurrent vomiting and poor feeding. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 2877 g (6 lb 6 oz); he currently weighs 2989 g (6 lb 9 oz). He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows weak muscle tone and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show increased serum concentrations of ketones and branched-chain organic acids. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.21 and an HCO3- concentration of 11 mEq/L. Further evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is seen in von Gierke disease and Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Von Gierke disease can also manifest during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, mild ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. However, von Gierke disease is not associated with the presence of branched-chain organic acids in serum. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome can cause failure to thrive and lethargy, both of which are seen here, but this disorder is usually asymptomatic for the first 6 months of life and it does not manifest with metabolic acidosis, ketosis, or organic acidemia; instead, it presents in childhood with choreoathetosis, dystonia, cognitive impairment, and self-mutilating behavior.

B) INCORRECT:

Myoglobinuria (due to rhabdomyolysis) is seen in carnitine palmitoyltransferase II deficiency (CPT II deficiency), which can manifest in the neonatal period with failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, metabolic acidosis, and increased serum levels of saturated and unsaturated dicarboxylic acids, both of which are organic acids. However, these dicarboxylic acids are unbranched unlike the increased serum concentrations of branched-chain organic acids that are seen in this neonate. In addition, CPT II deficiency does not result in ketosis; instead, it causes cardiomyopathy and/or arrhythmias.

C) CORRECT:

The organic acid accumulation that occurs in branched-chain organic acidemias causes hyperammonemia by inhibiting the urea cycle, a process that converts nitrogenous waste (e.g., ammonia) to urea for excretion. This organic acid build-up also inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes the oxidation of fatty acids to ketone bodies (an alternative energy source), thereby resulting in ketotic hypoglycemia. Increased serum concentrations of both ketones and branched-chain organic acids leads to high-anion gap metabolic acidosis. The most common type of branched-chain organic acidemia is methylmalonic acidemia (MMA), an autosomal recessive condition that is typically due to a defect in methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, an enzyme that converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. Other examples of branched-chain organic acidemias include propionic acidemia and isovaleric acidemia.

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is also associated with the accumulation of branched-chain organic acids (branched-chain Î±-keto acids) and metabolic acidosis but, for reasons that are not completely understood, hypoglycemia and hyperammonemia are unusual in patients with MSUD. Defects in fatty acid beta-oxidation (e.g., medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency) would also cause organic acid accumulation, hyperammonemia, and hypoglycemia but not ketosis. Also, the organic acids that accumulate in fatty acid oxidation defects are typically linear, unbranched dicarboxylic acids. Primary defects of the urea cycle (e.g., ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency) would result in hyperammonemia but not ketosis.
Image Description:

The amino acids methionine, isoleucine, valine, and threonine are metabolized to succinyl-CoA via propionyl-CoA and methylmalonyl-CoA. Succinyl-CoA is introduced into the citric acid cycle and can, when required, enter into gluconeogenesis via oxaloacetate.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucosuria can be seen in Fanconi syndrome, which can manifest with vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, failure to thrive, hypotonia, and metabolic acidosis (due to proximal RTA), all of which are seen here. In addition, hepatomegaly could be indicative of an underlying cause of Fanconi syndrome such as von Gierke disease or tyrosinemia. However, Fanconi syndrome is not associated with an increase in serum levels of branched-chain organic acids.

E) INCORRECT:

Galactosemia is seen in galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency (classic galactosemia), which can manifest during the neonatal period with vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, failure to thrive, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and metabolic acidosis (due to proximal RTA), all of which are seen here. However, it does not cause ketosis or organic acidemia. In addition, this neonate does not have other typical clinical features of classic galactosemia such as cataracts, diarrhea, and jaundice.

F) INCORRECT:

Orotic aciduria is caused by uridine monophosphate synthase (UMPS) deficiency, which can manifest during the neonatal period with failure to thrive, lethargy, and possibly metabolic acidosis due to high serum levels of orotic acid. However, orotic acid is not a branched-chain organic acid, and UMPS deficiency does not cause hypotonia, vomiting, hepatomegaly, or the presence of ketone bodies in serum; instead, orotic aciduria would cause megaloblastic anemia and urinary tract obstruction.
questions.hint: Metabolic acidosis (low pH with low HCO3-) and branched-chain organic acids in serum indicate a branched-chain organic acidemia, which typically manifests with vomiting, poor feeding, failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly within a few weeks to months of life.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of easy fatiguability and muscle pain. One month ago, she had an episode of sudden onset right-sided weakness and headache. She has a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures that are treated with antiepileptic drugs and frequent migraines associated with vomiting. Her mother and brother have similar symptoms. Her serum lactate concentration is 3.0 mmol/L (N = 0.5â€“2.2). Graded exercise testing shows a significantly decreased maximum rate of oxygen consumption. The activity of which of the following metabolic pathways is most likely increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol synthesis takes place in the cytosol, peroxisomes, and smooth endoplasmic reticulum, not in the mitochondria. However, acetyl CoA, which is the precursor for cholesterol synthesis, is produced in the mitochondria. MELAS, a mitochondrial disease, would decrease acetyl CoA production, so it would most likely decrease rather than increase cholesterol synthesis. In addition, the cellular energy deficit caused by mitochondrial diseases decreases energy-dependent processes such as cholesterol synthesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimidine synthesis takes place in the cytosol, not the mitochondria. However, the cellular deficit that occurs in mitochondrial diseases such as MELAS would most likely decrease rather than increase energy-dependent processes such as pyrimidine synthesis. Pyrimidine synthesis would be increased in malignant cells (e.g., leukemia cells).

C) INCORRECT:

MELAS is typically caused by a defect in a gene coding for mitochondrial tRNA. This defect would decrease rather than increase mitochondrial protein synthesis. In addition, the cellular energy deficit caused by mitochondrial diseases decreases energy-dependent processes such as protein synthesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxidative phosphorylation takes place in the mitochondria. In MELAS syndrome, mutations of mitochondrial DNA cause respiratory chain defects, resulting in decreased rather than increased oxidative phosphorylation. This is evident from the significantly decreased maximum VO2 in this patient.
Image Description:

A mitochondrion (bottom left, cross section) and its most important functions: Mitochondria are cell organelles made up of a smooth outer membrane, an inner membrane with an increased surface area as a result of folds (cristae), and the matrix, which harbors mitochondrial DNA and ribosomes and is the site of numerous metabolic processes.

Upper left: One of the most important functions of the mitochondria is supplying energy through the electron transport chain, which is integrated into the inner mitochondrial membrane. The phospholipid cardiolipin enables the close arrangement of individual complexes of the electron transport chain.

Upper right: The outer membrane is rich in pores and therefore permeable to numerous substances, whereas the inner membrane can only be permeated via specific transporters.

Bottom right: Proteins must be unfolded before transport in and out of the mitochondrion. Translocases of the inner and outer membranes (TIM and TOM) transport unfolded proteins across the membranes.

E) CORRECT:

MELAS syndrome is typically caused by a defect in genes coding for mitochondrial tRNA. This defect would decrease the synthesis of mitochondrial proteins, including enzymes of the citric acid cycle and mitochondrial respiratory chain, which are responsible for the majority of cellular ATP generation (via aerobic metabolism). In response to a lack of ATP and intermediates of the citric acid cycle (e.g., citrate), enzymes involved in glycolysis (a cytosolic process), such as phosphofructokinase-1, are upregulated. Glycolysis and the anaerobic metabolism of pyruvate generated via glycolysis then serve as the primary sources of ATP. Increased anaerobic metabolism of pyruvate to lactate is also responsible for the lactic acidosis seen in MELAS. ATP deficiency impairs the functioning of tissues that are highly energy-dependent (e.g., neurons, myocytes). Other processes that take place partly or completely in the mitochondria, such as fatty acid Î²-oxidation, ketogenesis, and the urea cycle, are also impaired. Decreased urea cycle activity and the lack of ketone bodies (an energy source for the brain) further contribute to encephalopathy in MELAS.

A muscle cell biopsy in patients with mitochondrial diseases, such as MELAS, usually shows cytosolic lipid accumulation (due to impaired fatty acid Î²-oxidation) and a ragged-red fiber appearance.
Image Description:

Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and is the metabolic pathway in which glucose is broken down into two pyruvate molecules, generating two molecules of ATP in the process (four ATP generated minus two ATP consumed). In the first phase of glycolysis, ATP (energy) is consumed. In the second and third phases, ATP and reducing equivalents (NADH) are generated.

Black boxes: reactants/products
Blue text: enzymes
Green text: electron carriers (NAD+, NADH+H+) or nucleotides (ATP, ADP) involved in energy consumption and production
Red text: energy (ATP) that is consumed (-) or produced (+) and reducing equivalents (NADH+H+) of each phase

F) INCORRECT:

Beta-oxidation, a mitochondrial process that converts fatty acids into acetyl CoA, serves as an alternative energy source and would be increased in conditions associated with impaired glycolysis or glycogenolysis (e.g., von Gierke disease). Mitochondrial diseases, such as MELAS, result in decreased rather than increased Î²-oxidation, and characteristically causes the accumulation of fatty acids in the cytosol.
Image Description:

Beta-oxidation of even-numbered fatty acids requires four enzymatic reactions, eventually yielding acyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA through cleavage of two carbons per cycle. This process is nearly identical in mitochondria and peroxisomes, except for some minor differences.

In peroxisomes, FADH2, which is generated during the first reaction, cannot undergo conversion to FAD through the respiratory chain but has to transfer its electrons onto oxygen. This reaction yields H2O2, which will subsequently be broken down into water and oxygen.

Moreover, beta-oxidation in peroxisomes does not allow for complete breakdown of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. Instead, carbon groups may only be cleaved off up to a chain length of at least eight remaining carbon atoms (octanyl-CoA). These fatty acids are then released into the cytosol and transferred to the mitochondria for complete breakdown. Acetyl-CoA generated in peroxisomes is also released into the cytosol to be used as substrate for other reactions, e.g., the mitochondrial citrate cycle.
questions.hint: Myopathy (e.g., fatigue, muscle pain), encephalopathy (e.g., seizures, headaches, vomiting), increased lactate levels, and stroke-like-episodes (e.g., sudden onset right-sided weakness) suggest MELAS syndrome, a hereditary mitochondrial disease. The presence of symptoms in this patient's mother and brother is consistent with mitochondrial inheritance.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of low performance in school since starting 1st grade 2 months ago. His mother reports that, according to his teachers, he always prefers to sit close to the blackboard. He continuously interrupts other children while they are talking and is unable to sit quietly through a classroom period. When he is asked by the teacher to stop, he bursts into tears and leaves the classroom. His parents say that â€œhe has always been a bit slower than his peers.â€ Physical examination shows pale skin, long and slender toes and fingers, and hunching of the back. Visual acuity is decreased bilaterally. His serum methionine concentration is increased. A deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

S-adenosyl methionine synthase converts methionine and ATP to S-adenosylmethionine, which is an intermediate substrate in the conversion of methionine to homocysteine. A deficiency of this enzyme can cause intellectual disability and an increased serum methionine concentration, as seen here. However, it would not explain the arachnodactyly, kyphosis, pale skin, and decreased visual acuity seen in this patient. Instead, features such as muscle weakness, facial dysmorphism, liver disease, and a boiled cabbage odor would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Methionine synthase converts homocysteine to methionine using vitamin B12 as a cofactor. Homocystinuria, which is responsible for this patient's clinical features, can be caused by methionine synthase deficiency, but a deficiency of this enzyme would be expected to cause a decrease rather than an increase in serum methionine concentration.

C) CORRECT:

Cystathionine synthase converts homocysteine and serine to cystathionine using vitamin B6 as a cofactor; a deficiency of this enzyme is one of the causes of homocystinuria. In homocystinuria caused by cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of vitamin B6 for cystathionine synthase, homocysteine is converted back to methionine by methionine synthase, resulting in an increased serum methionine concentration, as seen here. The treatment for cystathionine synthase deficiency consists of a diet low in methionine and rich in cysteine, and supplementation of vitamin B6, B12, and folate.
Image Description:

Methionine synthase deficiency or MTHFR deficiency: impaired conversion of homocysteine to methionine
Cystathionine synthase deficiency or reduced affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate: impaired conversion of homocysteine to cystathionine

Both result in accumulation of homocysteine.

Substances shown in blue text are enzymes (e.g., MTHFR). Substances shown in parentheses and blue shading are cofactors in enzymatic reactions (e.g., FAD). Substances shown in beige shading are B vitamins, highlighted here because treatment of homocystinuria may involve B vitamin supplementation.

PLP: pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B6); MTHFR: methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase; FAD: flavin adenine dinucleotide (derived from vitamin B2); THF: tetrahydrofolate (derived from vitamin B9)

D) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine hydroxylase hydroxylates phenylalanine to tyrosine, and a deficiency in this enzyme results in phenylketonuria. If untreated, phenylketonuria causes intellectual disability, behavioral changes, and pale skin, as seen here. However, this condition would not explain the arachnodactyly, kyphosis, decreased visual acuity, or increased serum methionine concentration seen in this patient. Moreover, neonatal screening would show increased serum phenyl ketones, and, if the condition went untreated, features such as failure to thrive, dermatitis, and/or a musty body odor would be expected as well.

E) INCORRECT:

Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase reduces N5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate to N5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which serves as a cofactor for the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. Homocystinuria, which is responsible for this patient's clinical features, can be caused by methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase deficiency. However, a deficiency of this enzyme would be expected to result in a decrease in serum methionine concentration, not an increase.
questions.hint: Intellectual disability, behavioral changes, arachnodactyly, kyphosis, decreased visual acuity, and light skin in a 6-year-old patient suggest hereditary homocystinuria, in which homocysteine accumulates in serum and is excreted in the urine. Hereditary homocystinuria can be caused by one of several autosomal recessive enzyme defects; the increase in serum methionine indicates which enzyme is deficient.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman with phenylketonuria that was diagnosed on newborn screening presents for a routine physical examination. At birth, her confirmatory phenylalanine level was 19.0 mg/dL (normal newborn range, 1.2â€“3.4 mg/dL). In early childhood, she maintained an average phenylalanine level of 5 mg/dL (treatment range, 2â€“6).
Today, she reports feeling self-conscious drinking phenylalanine-free formula at work because of the strong odor, and she says that there is no refrigerator at her workplace. She would like to be able to buy lunch in the workplace cafeteria and plans to follow a vegetarian diet.
What are the expected consequences, if any, of an unrestricted but vegetarian diet in this patient?

choices.text: None â€” a diet free of animal protein is sufficient to provide metabolic control
Hyperammonemia and acute mental status changes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A diet that restricts only animal-based proteins is insufficient for patients with PKU. The correct diet for PKU restricts the amino acid phenylalanine specifically. Specially formulated medical foods and formulas are needed to meet the patientâ€™s protein requirements while restricting phenylalanine. Although animal-based foods are a major source of protein, a vegetarian diet can also contain large amounts of proteins from legumes, and wheat flour-based products may contain substantial phenylalanine content, leading to suboptimal treatment of the disease.

B) CORRECT:

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme that metabolizes the amino acid phenylalanine. Several studies have shown that adolescents and adults with early-treated PKU have an increased incidence of self-reported moodiness and inattention as well as formally diagnosed disorders, including affective disorders, anxiety disorders, attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, and executive dysfunction. There is evidence that dietary liberalization during adolescence and adulthood contributes to these symptoms. However, as a population, even adolescents and adults with well-controlled PKU who have adhered to a restricted diet have an increased risk for mood disorders and executive dysfunction.

The main symptoms of PKU are neuropsychiatric, without the acute metabolic deregulations (e.g., acidosis, hypoglycemia, hyperammonemia) that occur in other inborn errors of metabolism.

Key learning point: The manifestations of poorly controlled phenylketonuria in adults are executive dysfunction, impulsivity, and mood dysregulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis are common manifestations of inborn errors of metabolism, specifically organic acidopathies. In these disorders, intermediates of amino acid breakdown that are acids cause acidosis and inhibit gluconeogenesis. However, in PKU, the primary defect is the inability to break down phenylalanine, and phenylalanine itself is neurotoxic. Given that phenylalanine is neither an acid nor involved in glucose homeostasis, acidosis and hypoglycemia do not develop in PKU.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperammonemia is a common manifestation of inborn errors of metabolism, most commonly urea cycle defects, which are amino acid metabolic defects in which the nitrogen of the amino acid cannot be metabolized, resulting in ammonia buildup. Nitrogen metabolism is not affected in PKU.

E) INCORRECT:

PKU that is not treated during infancy (with dietary restriction of phenylalanine) results in severe cognitive decline and progressive dysmyelination that are not reversible with later treatment. Children who are treated during infancy avoid these severe consequences, even if they go off a restricted diet in late childhood or adolescence. However, they may still have residual neuropsychiatric symptoms even if their intelligence is in the normal range.

questions.text:
A one-week-old girl is being evaluated after the stateâ€™s newborn screening laboratory reported that her screening results were suggestive of medium-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase deficiency.
The infantâ€™s birth weight was 2900 g, and she now weighs 2880 g. The mother reports that her daughter is breastfeeding well every 2 to 3 hours and is having eight to ten bowel movements or wet diapers per day. The parents have not observed any poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, or hypotonia.
There is no family history of known metabolic diseases.
The infantâ€™s physical examination is normal; no hepatomegaly is detectable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this infant?

choices.text: Instruct the parents to have the child return for evaluation if she develops poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, or hypotonia.
Recommend adjunctive feeding with dextrose dissolved in water twice daily, and arrange confirmatory testing
Refer the child to the emergency department for further evaluation with consultation from a metabolic specialist
Initiate treatment with cornstarch, and arrange for confirmatory testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Newborn screening tests do not provide a definitive diagnosis, so that this point, repeat screening would be inadequate. Follow-up testing for possible MCAD should not be delayed and must be part of the immediate next steps in this patient's care.

B) INCORRECT:

The appropriate next steps for a newborn whose screening test is positive for a metabolic disorder are consultation with a metabolic specialist and further testing to confirm the diagnosis. This approach is proactive and does not wait for the development of symptoms, which may be life-threatening.

C) INCORRECT:

Dextrose dissolved in water would temporarily increase â€” but not effectively maintain â€” appropriate blood sugar levels. It would also be inappropriate for a one-week-old neonate.

D) CORRECT:

The appropriate next steps for a newborn whose screening test is positive for a metabolic disorder are consultation with a metabolic specialist and further testing to confirm the diagnosis. Given that there are many published cases of infants with medium-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency presenting in extremis very early in life, such consultation and testing should be done urgently. Often, this is done through the emergency department, where confirmatory testing can be sent quickly and the family can be educated about the importance of fasting avoidance.

Newborn screening programs typically provide comprehensive advice for responding to positive results. The responsibilities of the primary care provider are to:

â€¢ Communicate clearly with the family
â€¢ Facilitate further testing and subspecialty referral
â€¢ Provide oversight to ensure follow-up and, when needed, continued subspecialty care

MCAD Deficiency

MCAD deficiency is a fatty-acid oxidation disorder that impairs the use of fat for energy during fasting or times of increased caloric demand (e.g., illness). The classic presentation is hypoketotic hypoglycemia with progressive neurologic changes during an illness or prolonged fasting. These episodes may be fatal. Early diagnosis of MCAD enables initiation of dietary management that can be lifesaving.

MCAD often surfaces between 3 months and 2 years of age, when children begin to go for longer periods of time between meals. Infants who feed every 2 to 3 hours are typically asymptomatic.

Key learning point: A positive neonatal screening test for metabolic disease should prompt consultation with a metabolic specialist and confirmatory testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Cornstarch may be used to manage fatty-acid oxidation disorders, but its use is not necessary for an asymptomatic child who is breastfeeding without difficulty.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl with phenylketonuria that was diagnosed on newborn screening presents for a well visit. At birth, her confirmatory phenylalanine level was 19.0 mg/dL (normal newborn range, 1.2â€“3.4 mg/dL). In early childhood, she maintained an average phenylalanine level of 5 mg/dL (treatment range, 2â€“6).
Today, she reports feeling self-conscious drinking phenylalanine-free formula at school because of the strong odor, and she says that the school has no way to refrigerate it for her. She would like to be allowed to buy lunch in the school cafeteria and plans to follow a vegetarian diet.
What are the expected consequences, if any, of an unrestricted but vegetarian diet in this patient?

None â€” a diet free of animal protein is sufficient to provide metabolic control
