questions.text:
A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department (ED) in a lethargic state. His parents report that he appeared well at bedtime but did not wake up to feed overnight and, in the morning, he was difficult to arouse and felt warm to the touch.
On examination, he has a temperature of 39.0Â°C, a heart rate of 190 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli. He has a third heart sound (S3 gallop). His liver is palpable 1 cm below the costal margin. A point-of-care fingerstick test shows a glucose level of 42 mg/dL (60â€“100).
Urinalysis results are normal, with no detectable ketones. A complete metabolic panel is notable for an alanine aminotransferase level of 50 U/liter (reference range, 13â€“45) and an aspartate aminotransferase level of 400 U/liter (9â€“80).
Chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette with normal lung markings.
Review of the patientâ€™s medical record reveals that a newborn screen sent at 36 hours of life was normal.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patientâ€™s symptoms?

choices.text: Very long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carnitine, an essential nutrient for shuttling fatty acids into the mitochondria for oxidation, is provided in the diet by animal products and is present in relatively low amounts in breast milk. Very severe carnitine deficiency can impair fatty-acid oxidation; however, such cases are usually caused by an inherited defect in carnitine transport rather than diet. The clinical manifestations are usually much milder than those seen in this patient, even in cases of severe carnitine deficiency. Affected patients tend to present between the ages of 3 months and 2 years with hepatomegaly, hyperammonemia, and hypoketotic hypoglycemia. Heart disease is usually observed between 2 and 4 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Glycogen storage disease (GSD) type 1 causes hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. However, because fatty-acid oxidation is not impaired in GSD-1, this disease is usually characterized by adequate ketosis in response to hypoglycemia. This disease is not associated with cardiomyopathy so would not be expected to present with a gallop or enlarged heart on radiograph. In addition, the hepatomegaly is usually much more severe than in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Peroxisomal biogenesis disorders, such as Zellweger spectrum, are characterized by an increase in very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), but the VLCFAs in this disorder are distinct from those of VLCAD deficiency, and the two disorders are biochemically unrelated. Peroxisomal biogenesis disorders often cause embryologic abnormalities, chronic hepatopathy, sensorineural hearing loss, and cataracts, but they do not provoke acute metabolic crisis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperinsulinism, including the hyperinsulinism-hyperammonemia syndrome (HIHA), causes hypoketotic hypoglycemia because insulin inhibits fatty-acid oxidation. However, cardiomyopathy and myopathy are not features of HIHA. Furthermore, patients with HIHA usually experience postprandial hypoglycemia, specifically after a high-protein meal, because the specific mutation involved causes increased insulin secretion in response to the amino acid leucine.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has hypoketotic hypoglycemia, cardiomyopathy (causing an S3 gallop, enlarged heart, and hepatomegaly), and a highly elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level. Together, these findings suggest a long-chain fatty-acid oxidation defect, such as very long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (VLCAD) deficiency.

All fatty-acid oxidation defects share the hallmark feature of hypoketotic hypoglycemia provoked by extended fasting, increased energy demands (such as fever), or both. Fatty-acid oxidation is physiologically necessary for two reasons:

â€¢ The generation of ketones as a glucose-sparing fuel
â€¢ The provision of adenosine triphosphate to power gluconeogenesis

Ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis are not used by most people in day-to-day life; these processes provide energy during periods of extended fasting (12â€“16 hours after eating) and in times of increased energy demands.

In disorders such as VLCAD deficiency, the accumulating long-chain fatty acids are toxic because they intercalate into the phospholipid bilayer and cause cell lysis. This is especially harmful to the tissues that rely most on fatty-acid oxidation â€” skeletal and cardiac myocytes, as well as hepatocytes â€” and can lead to rhabdomyolysis, dilated cardiomyopathy, and acute fatty-liver disease. Because the brain also relies heavily on ketones, patients with fatty-acid oxidation disorders have more-striking mental status changes during crisis than the degree of hypoglycemia alone would predict.

When clinical suspicion for VLCAD deficiency is high but the newborn screen is normal (as in this case), the diagnosis should remain high on the differential because the sensitivity of proper newborn screening is lower for this disorder than for others. There have been several case reports of false negatives where infants who had normal newborn screening results have subsequently suffered metabolic decompensation or death from VLCAD deficiency.

Key learning point: The hallmark sign of a fatty-acid oxidation defect is hypoketotic hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
The parents of an 11-month-old female infant find her unarousable in her crib at 8:00 in the morning and bring her to the emergency department (ED). They report that she was acting normally the night before and drank 240 mL (8 ounces) of formula before going to bed at 8:00 in the evening. She has not had any formula since then, as they are weaning her from nighttime feedings.
On examination, the patient is lethargic and floppy. She is afebrile and has a heart rate of 130 beats per minute; the rest of her vital signs and examination are normal. She has no palpable hepatomegaly.
Point-of-care testing reveals a glucose level of 27 mg/dL, and the insulin level is undetectable. A urinalysis is notable for no ketones.
After a bolus of 10% dextrose solution is administered, the patientâ€™s mental status improves, and she is alert and interactive.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to obtain next in this patient?

choices.text: Anti-islet cell, anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase, and anti-insulin antibody testing
Toxicology screen for oral hypoglycemic agents

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-islet cell, anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase, and anti-insulin antibodies are typically evaluated when patients present with new-onset diabetes. Such patients would present with hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.

B) CORRECT:

Hypoglycemia in children has many potential causes that can be rapidly differentiated from one another based on (1) when the hypoglycemia occurred relative to the most recent meal, (2) whether ketosis is present, (3) whether the childâ€™s insulin level is appropriate, and (4) whether hepatomegaly is evident. Although many diagnostic algorithms exist, the best insight comes from understanding physiologic glucose control.

Immediately after an individual eats, increased glucose levels in the portal circulation cause glucose-stimulated insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells. Thus, hypoglycemia that develops within the first 3 hours after a meal is likely a consequence either of defects in carbohydrate metabolism (as in galactosemia or fructosemia, diseases in which dietary sugars cannot be metabolized) or of hyperinsulinism resulting from inappropriate release of insulin.

Outside of meal times, glycogen is the primary source of circulating blood glucose. During prolonged periods of fasting (>8 hours), gluconeogenesis and fatty-acid oxidation (resulting in ketone formation) help provide the brain and heart with metabolic fuel. When hypoglycemia occurs during prolonged fasting, defects in glycogen metabolism, gluconeogenesis, and fatty-acid oxidation should be considered.

This patient presents with hypoketotic hypoglycemia after a 12-hour fast and has an appropriately undetectable insulin level and no palpable hepatomegaly. The timing of the hypoglycemia and the lack of hepatomegaly strongly suggest that the problem is a defect of fatty-acid oxidation. This disorder classically manifests in infants between 6 to 12 months of age with the introduction of weaning from night feeds and is suggested in this particular patient by the absence of appropriate ketogenesis.

An acylcarnitine profile is the appropriate test for fatty-acid oxidation defects and must be obtained while the patient is ill; once calories are supplied and lipolysis stops, the test may normalize.

Key learning point: Fatty-acid oxidation disorders in infants who are being weaned from nighttime feedings and are therefore fasting for 8 to 12 hours manifest as hypoketotic hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Ingestion of oral hypoglycemic agents is an important consideration in children with hypoglycemia. However, most accidental ingestions occur in children who are slightly older than this patient and thus more developmentally capable of reaching medications. Furthermore, most of the oral hypoglycemic agents that can provoke clinically significant hypoglycemia, such as sulfonylureas, do so by encouraging insulin release, such that the insulin level would be elevated in the case of an ingestion.

D) INCORRECT:

Uric acid and triglyceride levels can be used to establish the diagnosis of glycogen storage disease type 1, in which no glycogen can be mobilized. Because glycogen accumulates in the liver, this condition is characterized by massive hepatomegaly. Although this disease may manifest with hypoketotic hypoglycemia, the lack of hepatomegaly on this patientâ€™s examination makes it less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Genetic hyperinsulinism causes hypoglycemia and, in particular, hypoketotic hypoglycemia because insulin inhibits the availability of fatty acids for ketone production by inhibiting triglyceride breakdown. However, the pattern of hypoglycemia in hyperinsulinism is chaotic and occurs with short periods of fasting. Although the insulin level in hyperinsulinism may not be "high," it is always high relative to the glucose level. This patientâ€™s insulin level is undetectable.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl with a history of significant developmental delay is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of dyspnea on exertion. Her parents report that during the past week, she has been breathing heavily after playing. She has no history of asthma. She initially started walking at 13 months of age and spoke her first word at 15 months, but at 18 months, she had a fever to 39.0Â°C and lost the ability to walk and talk. She wears hearing aids in both ears. Her family history is significant only for maternal retinitis pigmentosa.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 38.5Â°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. She has short stature, bilateral ptosis, and a new 2/6 heart murmur at the left lower sternal border; the cardiac point of maximal impulse is displaced inferolaterally. She has truncal hypotonia with slow, apparently involuntary movements of the arms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Kussmaul respirations because of lactic acidosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Leigh syndrome is a genetic disease, congenital anomalies outside the central nervous system (CNS), such as cystic congenital adenomatoid malformations, are not commonly associated. Occasionally, CNS anomalies (most often dysgenesis of the corpus callosum) can be associated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has Leigh syndrome, a pediatric mitochondrial phenotype characterized by developmental regression between 1 and 3 years of age, typically following a fever or other metabolic stressor, such as anesthesia. Usually the regression primarily affects subcortical structures, such as basal ganglia, resulting in gross-motor regression, dysarthria, and choreiform movements. An MRI classically shows bilateral necrotizing encephalopathy of the basal ganglia, visualized as an abnormal signal. Other subcortical areas â€” such as the periaqueductal gray matter, thalamus, and brainstem â€” may also be involved.

Multiorgan involvement is common in primary mitochondrial disease, and clinicians should take care to recognize common comorbidities, including failure to thrive, retinitis pigmentosa, sensorineural hearing loss, hypertrophic or dilated cardiomyopathy, liver steatosis, renal tubular acidosis, and myopathy. This patientâ€™s clinical findings â€” exercise intolerance, dyspnea, a new heart murmur, and displacement of the point of maximal impact â€” are most consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Mitochondrial disease can be inherited either in a Mendelian fashion from one or both parents â€” or maternally through mutations in mitochondrial DNA. In the latter case, symptom severity may be determined by the percentage of mitochondrial DNA that is mutated (the heteroplasmy). This percentage can be variable within families and between generations; as a result, severely affected children are often born to mothers who have more subtle features of disease.

Key learning point: In patients with Leigh syndrome, the most important cardiac consideration is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Children with hypotonia of any cause are at increased risk for pneumonia related to poor respiratory clearance â€” an important consideration for children with Leigh syndrome. However, a patient with pneumonia would be expected to have fever and focal lung-examination findings, without the cardiac features seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrioventricular (AV) block is evident in some mitochondrial diseases, most commonly Kearns-Sayre syndrome, and is not particularly associated with Leigh syndrome. Symptoms of AV block include an irregular heart rate, dizziness, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Cardiac enlargement and murmur would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with mitochondrial disease may have elevated lactate levels that fluctuate in severity with disease subtype, age, and exposure to stressors. Some levels can be high enough to cause metabolic acidosis and changes in breathing patterns. This patientâ€™s respiratory rate is not consistent with Kussmaul respirations seen with severe metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with increasing sleepiness after 6 hours of irritability and acting out. Her parents note that 2 days ago, she had nasal congestion and a fever of 38.4Â°C that lasted for 4 hours and then resolved with antipyretics. Yesterday, she attended a family barbeque and ate two hot dogs; 3 hours later, she developed nausea and had an episode of nonbloody emesis. Her parents mention that she typically prefers to eat vegetables.
Her family history is significant for a maternal uncle who died in infancy after an acute illness with hyperammonemia (ammonia level >1000 Î¼g/dL). He was suspected of having ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency.
On physical examination, the patient has mild tachypnea (respiratory rate, 40 breaths per minute). She appears lethargic but arouses to tactile and vocal stimuli. Her vital signs are stable, and her pupils are round, regular, and reactive. Abdominal examination shows a mildly palpable liver but no fluid wave or shifting dullness. Neurologic examination shows evidence of increased tone in the upper and lower extremities, associated with hyperreflexia, as well as bilateral clonus. The examination is interrupted by a tonic-clonic seizure that lasts 5 seconds and ends spontaneously.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
40
22â€“26


Urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
2
5â€“18


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.4
0.3â€“0.7


Ammonia (Î¼g/dL)
800
15â€“45


A complete blood count shows a mild leukocytosis. An electroencephalogram demonstrates signs of generalized encephalopathy.
The parents report that the patient has had no exposure to sick contacts and has not accidentally consumed any toxic material or medications. She has no history of diabetes or previous episodes of hypoglycemia.
What is the mode of inheritance of this patientâ€™s likely metabolic condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, an X-linked disease, not an autosomal dominant disease.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, an X-linked disease that causes profound hyperammonemia with or without liver dysfunction. Boys are usually more severely affected and usually present early in the neonatal period. Some girls become symptomatic because of skewed X-inactivation and present (at varying ages) when challenged with excessive protein intake, febrile-related illnesses, and vomiting. Hyperammonemia is a life-threatening condition that, if not immediately treated, can acutely lead to brain edema and death. Long-term complications of the disease include global developmental delay and cognitive and learning disabilities. Excessive protein in the diet, physiological stress (including from fasting or fever), catabolic events (e.g., infections, vomiting, dehydration), and use of medications such as valproic acid can precipitate severe hyperammonemia in patients with OTC deficiency.

Newborn screening is normal in OTC deficiency and, therefore, does not help to detect potential cases. However, orotic acid levels may be elevated if measured in the neonatal period.

Noninvasive diagnostic testing of OTC deficiency involves identifying pathogenic mutations or deletions in the OTC gene. Biochemical testing for OTC is confirmed once there is evidence of:

â€¢ Hyperammonemia
â€¢ A low citrulline concentration and elevated glutamine concentration on plasma amino acid analysis
â€¢ An elevated urinary orotic acid level

Liver biopsy for enzymatic testing may also reveal the diagnosis, but this evaluation is invasive.

The presentation of OTC deficiency in girls may vary according to the degree of skewed X-inactivation and remaining enzyme activity. Girls may be asymptomatic carriers or show varying manifestations of hyperammonemia, including neuropsychiatric symptoms, lethargy, seizures, encephalopathy, and (if untreated) brain edema and death.

Acute management involves quickly lowering the ammonia level by restricting protein intake while preventing catabolism, as well as promoting anabolism using dextrose intravenous fluids. Hemodialysis may be indicated in severe cases.

Chronic management involves a combination of dietary protein restriction, administration of ammonia-scavenging agents, and avoidance of catabolic states. Liver transplantation is curative and is indicated in patients with poor metabolic control, recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia, or both.

Key learning point: The inheritance pattern of ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is X-linked.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, an X-linked disease, not a mitochondrial disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, an X-linked disease, not a multifactorial disease.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, an X-linked disease, not an autosomal recessive disease.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy is brought in for evaluation of difficulty feeding, hypotonia, and episodes of spasticity during the past month that seemed to start 2 weeks after a self-limited viral illness with one day of fever. His family recently moved to the area from out of state. At the age of 2 months, he was noted to show poor weight gain, no linear growth despite increasing head size, and head lag. A brain MRI was done at the time and showed widening of sylvian fissures and anterior temporal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces with hyperintensity of the basal ganglia. The patient was referred to a specialist but was not able to be seen before moving.
He was born full term to a 25-year-old mother with no previous pregnancies. The pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. At birth, his weight and length were normal, and his head circumference was at the 90th percentile. He has been exclusively breastfed.
A review of his records shows an abnormal newborn screen for elevated glutarylcarnitine. The parents do not recall being told of these results but note that things have been difficult between the move, the new baby, and their older children. There is no family history of macrocephaly, developmental delay, or genetic conditions.
On examination, the patientâ€™s weight and length are at the 3rd and 5th percentiles, and his head circumference is at the 98th percentile. He is awake during the examination but is unable to lift his head when prone or move from side to side. On neurologic examination, he has truncal hypotonia, with increased tone in the upper extremities, and hyperreflexia.
Laboratory testing shows a significantly elevated glutarylcarnitine concentration, elevated concentrations of glutaric acid and 3-hydroxyglutaric acid in the urine, and low plasma carnitine concentrations.
In addition to referring to genetics for further evaluation and adding carnitine supplementation, which one of the following dietary modifications should be initiated?

choices.text: Switch to formula feeding with a soy-based formula
Add branched-chain amino acid-free formula with supplemental breastfeeding
Switch to formula feeding with a medium-chain triglyceride-containing formula and avoid fasting
Switch to formula feeding with a lysine-free and tryptophan-restricted formula
Add phenylalanine-free formula with supplemental breastfeeding

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Complete replacement of breastmilk with soy-based formula is recommended for patients with galactosemia. It would not limit protein intake as is needed in patients with GA1.

B) INCORRECT:

A formula low in branched-chain amino acids is appropriate for patients with maple syrup urine disease but does not limit lysine and tryptophan as needed for patients with GA1.

C) INCORRECT:

Replacement of breastmilk with medium-chain triglyceride-containing formula and avoidance of fasting is indicated for infants with very-long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders, but not those with GA1.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has glutaric acidemia type 1 (GA1), a cerebral organic aciduria that is inherited through an autosomal recessive pattern. Screening for this condition is included on newborn screening panels in most of the United States, but the results can be missed or lost to follow-up, especially if the patient relocates or has unstable housing or primary care.

Macrocephaly is the earliest sign of GA1 and may be present in 75% of cases. Patients are often free of neurologic symptoms at birth and may remain so with appropriate diagnosis and treatment. However, if left untreated, most patients with GA1 will experience an acute encephalopathic crisis between the ages of 3 months and 6 years, usually in response to a physiologic stressor, such as viral infection, vomiting, or fever. Subdural hematomas may also occur and are easily mistaken for nonaccidental trauma.

GA1 is caused by mutations in the GCDH gene, which codes for glutaryl-CoA dehydrogenase. Dysfunction of this enzyme causes an excess accumulation of glutaric acid and 3-hydroxyglutaric acid, which induce neurotoxicity. The conjugation of glutaric acid to carnitine results in glutarylcarnitine (C5DC), which is the basis of newborn screening for GA1. The accumulation of glutaric acid and 3-hydroxyglutaric acid results in structural brain abnormalities that are visible on MRI, including basal ganglia atrophy, widening of sylvian fissures, immature gyral pattern, and delayed myelination. Of note, brain MRI findings are variable and present on a spectrum that typically correlates with disease severity.

Additional biochemical testing can help to differentiate between GA1 and other inborn errors of metabolism. Canavan disease, for example, is a cerebral organic aciduria that manifests with macrocephaly, but the key biochemical feature is elevated urinary N-acetylaspartate, not glutaric acid. Multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency, also known as glutaric acidemia type 2, is a fatty-acid oxidation disorder that does not manifest with macrocephaly and results in multiple acylcarnitine elevations, which include C5DC.

Dietary management of GA1 in infants and children is generally focused on preventing encephalopathy by reducing the offending amino acids (lysine and tryptophan) that are catabolized to form glutaryl-CoA. To this end, protein is restricted, and amino acids are supplemented through formula. Formulas for patients with GA1 should be lysine-free and tryptophan-restricted. Importantly, the formula should not be entirely free of tryptophan as this can lead to neurologic deficits. Intake of natural protein sources, including breastmilk, formula, and solid foods, should be monitored to ensure appropriate intake of lysine. Carnitine supplementation may aid in excretion of glutaric acid as glutarylcarnitine.

Key learning point: Macrocephaly, basal ganglia atrophy, abnormal movement, hypotonia, and elevated plasma glutarylcarnitine levels are characteristic of glutaric acidemia type 1.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine-free formula is necessary for infants with phenylketonuria. If such infants are followed closely by a metabolic specialist, mothers can breastfeed partially. This diet would not be appropriately restricted for this patient.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department with vomiting and poor oral intake. Her parents report that she had a fever of 38.3Â°C last night and was fussy and irritable for a few hours until the fever resolved and she fell asleep. She then woke up vomiting and has had three episodes of vomiting during the past 5 hours. She has had no sick contacts and has otherwise been well until now.
On physical examination, she has shallow, rapid breathing and appears lethargic. Her pupils are equal, round, regular, and reactive. Her right tympanic membrane is red and bulging without discharge, although there is cerumen in the canal that is noted to have an odor. Other than an increased respiratory rate, her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with no evidence of murmurs or gallops.
During the examination, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure for one minute. Neurologic examination afterward is significant for somnolence, generalized hypertonia, and pedaling movements in the lower extremities. Reflexes are brisk throughout.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
9
19â€“24


Anion gap (mEq/liter)
20
8â€“12


Lactate (mmol/liter)
1.5
0.5â€“2.2


Glucose (mg/dL)
80
60â€“100


Ammonia (Î¼g/dL)
45
29â€“70


Urine ketones
Positive (strong)
Negative


In consultation with a metabolic geneticist by phone, you obtain further laboratory testing. Plasma amino acid analysis shows elevated leucine, isoleucine, valine, and alloisoleucine. Urine organic acid analysis shows metabolic products of isoleucine, valine, and leucine (alpha-keto acids including alpha-ketoisocaproic acid), as well as ketones. An acylcarnitine profile is normal. Review of the medical record shows no results from newborn screening, which the parents declined at birth.
The patient is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit for stabilization in concordance with the recommendations of the genetic-metabolic team.
After the patient is stabilized and ready to transition to an oral diet, which one of the following interventions is most important?

choices.text: Place the child on a diet consisting of a phenylalanine-free formula
Place the child on a diet consisting of a formula restricted in branched-chain amino acids
Place the child on a diet consisting of a soy-based formula
Place the child on a diet consisting of a high-protein formula

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low phenylalanine is the treatment for phenylketonuria, not MSUD.

B) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). MSUD is an autosomal recessive inborn error of amino acid metabolism characterized by impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs). The disorder is caused by deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKAD) enzymes. The cofactor for the BCKAD complex is thiamine (vitamin B1). Infants with MSUD are asymptomatic at birth until challenged by protein or a catabolic condition, such as the febrile illness with otitis media in this case. Presentations of MSUD vary, with more severe manifestations in early-onset disease (classic MSUD) and milder manifestations in late-onset disease. A hallmark of this disorder is a burnt-sugar or caramel odor in the urine, sweat, and cerumen. Elevations in BCAAs (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) can be detected within 12 hours of the acute onset of an MSUD exacerbation, and elevated urine ketones can be an early sign of metabolic decompensation. This patientâ€™s plasma analysis showed notable elevations in BCAAs and alloisoleucine (a specific marker for MSUD), and her urine analysis showed metabolic products of BCAAs (including alpha-ketoisocaproic acid) as well as ketones. Newborn screening for MSUD allows for early identification and treatment before symptoms appear. Confirming the diagnosis is necessary and is achieved by detecting elevated BCAAs in plasma or their metabolites on urine organic acids with or without genetic mutation testing. The presence of leucine-related metabolites is the most concerning because if left unchecked, it can lead to cerebral edema, which can cause compression (herniation) of the medulla, respiratory failure, and death. Early dietary intervention in MSUD, before the onset of symptoms, allows for normal growth and neurocognitive function and prevents complications. During acute metabolic decompensation, total protein restriction is recommended for the first 24 to 48 hours to treat elevation of BCAA metabolites. A high-concentration glucose infusion (goal infusion rate, 8â€“15 mg/kg/min) should be initiated along with treatment of any underlying infection or precipitating factors in order to promote anabolism and prevent catabolism. Chronic management of MSUD requires a therapeutic diet that restricts the offending amino acids (in this case, BCAAs) while providing sufficient amounts of natural protein to allow BCAA levels to remain within the normal range. Serial monitoring of BCAA levels is recommended to ensure that dietary modifications are adequately maintaining leucine and other BCAA levels within the normal range.

Key learning point: The goal of dietary management in maple syrup urine disease is to restrict branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine).

C) INCORRECT:

Soy-based formula is used in galactosemia, not MSUD. Infants with galactosemia require soy-based formula to avoid the galactose that makes up lactose in cowâ€™s milk-based formulas. Soy formula would be too high in protein for a child with MSUD.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 is often used therapeutically in patients with methylmalonic acidemia but is not indicated in MSUD. Thiamine (vitamin B1) is the cofactor used for the defective enzyme in MSUD; rarely, patients with MSUD may be thiamine responsive, but they still require dietary restriction.

E) INCORRECT:

High-protein formula, which would include the offending BCAAs, is contraindicated in MSUD. Such formula may be used in some premature infants to promote growth.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department because of somnolence and rapid breathing. He is exclusively breastfed and has been spitting up after each feed. His weight is down 12% from his birth weight.
On physical examination, he is afebrile and appears lethargic but is arousable. He has tachypnea and appears dehydrated. Cardiovascular examination is notable for tachycardia with a short systolic murmur and no gallop. Pulmonary examination demonstrates rapid, shallow breathing. Breath sounds are heard bilaterally with no evidence of rales or wheezes.
Blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures are sent. A 20-mL/kg bolus of intravenous normal saline is administered, and the infant is started on intravenous ampicillin and cefotaxime. He is admitted to the hospital.
Several hours later, the state laboratory notifies you that the patientâ€™s newborn screening showed an elevated propionylcarnitine (C3) level. Urgent laboratory testing yields the following results:

What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis occur in glycogen storage disease type 1 and medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. However, hyperammonemia does not occur in glycogen storage disease type 1, and ketosis is not common in medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis occur in glycogen storage disease type 1 and medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. However, hyperammonemia does not occur in glycogen storage disease type 1, and ketosis is not common in medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

C) CORRECT:

This infant is presenting in metabolic crisis, most likely due to either propionic acidemia (PA) or methylmalonic acidemia (MMA). PA and MMA are both organic acidurias that manifest with vomiting, lethargy, hypotonia, hypoglycemia, hyperammonemia, lactic acidosis with a high anion gap, and elevated propionyl carnitine levels. These two disorders, both inherited through an autosomal recessive pattern, are caused by enzyme defects in the propionic acid metabolism pathway â€” specifically a deficiency in propionyl-coenzyme A (CoA) carboxylase in the case of PA and in methylmalonyl-CoA mutase in MMA.

Newborns are screened for propionylcarnitine (typically reported as C3) levels, which are elevated in both PA and MMA. Further workup to clarify the diagnosis includes urine organic acid testing and an acylcarnitine serum panel. Urine organic acid testing will reveal elevated methylmalonic acid and methylcitrate levels in MMA and elevated propionic acid, 3-OH propionic acid, methylcitrate, and propionylglycine levels in PA.

The hyperammonemia in PA and MMA is secondary to inhibition of urea generation. These conditions are also characterized by metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap, lactic acidosis, and ketonuria (with or without hypoglycemia).

Of note, elevated C3 on newborn screening is the marker for propionic and methylmalonic aciduria and is not present in any of the other conditions mentioned above. Newborn screening for PA and MMA allows for early detection and treatment, typically before symptoms occur, reducing long-term risks of morbidity and mortality, although some infants, as in this case, may present before testing is complete.

Key learning point: Vomiting, lethargy, ketosis, hyperammonemia, lactic acidosis, high anion gap, and elevated propionyl carnitine levels are signs of propionic or methylmalonic acidemia.

D) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is a structural cardiac defect that may be associated with tachycardia, tachypnea, and lactic acidosis when it is severe or associated with a shunt. However, hyperammonemia and ketosis do not occur in VSD.

E) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (a urea cycle disorder) is associated with hyperammonemia and respiratory alkalosis, not lactic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 4-day-old term neonate is brought to the clinic due to poor feeding, frequent vomiting, and diminishing alertness. The birth was uncomplicated, and prenatal care was consistent. Physical examination shows decreased tone and occasional jitteriness. The diaper has a distinctive, sweet odor. Newborn screening results are not yet available (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



pH
7.30
7.36 - 7.45


Leucine
500 Âµmol/L
50 - 200 Âµmol/L



Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, a urea cycle disorder, presents with hyperammonemia and neurological symptoms. It does not cause elevated branched-chain amino acids. The increased leucine level and sweet odor suggest a defect in amino acid metabolism, not a urea cycle defect. Mild acidemia aligns more with disorders affecting branched-chain amino acid catabolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Tyrosinemia type I is due to fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency, leading to toxic metabolite accumulation and liver dysfunction. It is associated with a cabbage-like odor, not a sweet odor. Laboratory findings typically show elevated tyrosine levels, not leucine. The absence of liver failure signs and elevated leucine level make tyrosinemia type I unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Maple syrup urine disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency in the branched-chain Î±-keto acid dehydrogenase complex. This deficiency impairs the oxidative decarboxylation of branched-chain amino acids, such as leucine, leading to their accumulation. The elevated serum leucine level reflects this disrupted catabolism, resulting in neurotoxic effects like poor feeding, lethargy, hypotonia, and jitteriness. The sweet odor in the diaper is due to the accumulation of specific keto acids and their metabolites, a hallmark of this condition. Additionally, metabolic acidosis, indicated by a reduced blood pH, supports the metabolic derangements associated with this enzymatic defect.

Key learning point: Maple Syrup Urine Disease is characterized by the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids and presents with symptoms such as poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and sweet-smelling urine in newborns.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenylketonuria results from a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to phenylalanine accumulation. It is characterized by a musty or mousy odor, not a sweet odor. The elevated leucine level and sweet odor in this neonate are inconsistent with phenylketonuria, which does not typically involve branched-chain amino acids.
